name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I would like to make one announcement. I want to inform the House that yesterday the Ethiopian authorities freed the opposition leader Merera Gudina after more than a year in detention. Dr Gudina was arrested in November 2016 at Addis Ababa airport after he flew in from Brussels where he had attended a meeting in the European Parliament. In its previous resolutions Parliament had called for the release of Dr Gudina, so we therefore wholeheartedly welcome this decision. This House will always be strongly committed to the defence of human rights.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the report by Nicola Danti, on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, on the implementation of Directive 2005/36/EC as regards regulation and the need for reform in professional services (2017/2073(INI)) (A8—0401/2017).

name: Nicola DANTI
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, there are more than 5 500 regulated professions in Europe today, to which many other non-regulatory professions must be added. This is a picture that varies greatly from country to country — ranging from 76 regulated professions in Lithuania up to 543 in Hungary — and involving 22% of the European workforce. With the report we present today for debate and vote in this House, Parliament intends to respond to the Communication from the European Commission on recommendations for reform in services professional. This initiative should be welcomed, having the merit of providing an overall assessment of the state of implementation of that directive and an overview of the rules applicable in the different Member States to architects, civil engineers, accountants, lawyers, industrial property consultants, real estate agents and tour guides. The communication shows first of all the need to fully implement the provisions of the Directive. In the world of professions, there is a need for greater mobility and more competition, and the Commission document undeniably emerges relevant areas for manoeuvre in the legislation of the Member States. On the other hand, I believe that any assessment of the effectiveness and proportionality of national legislation should be taken taking into account not only economic and quantitative factors, as is all too often the case and emerges from reading the documents of the European Commission. The direct link identified between reform and economic growth, between deregulation and the creation of new jobs, cannot and should not be the only polar star for policymakers. Instead, it is important to reiterate that the quality of professional services is one of the key factors in preserving our social and economic model and to ensure the competitiveness of our economy. For this reason, it is necessary to promote rules which, on the one hand, support young people's access to the world of work, growth and innovation but which, at the same time, protect the quality of the services provided, public interest targets and consumers. In order to assess the regulation of the professions, a combination of economic considerations and political assessments in defence of the general public objectives is therefore necessary, while respecting non-discrimination and proportionality provided for in the Treaties. In order to preserve a high quality of professional services, we need not only an effective and proportionate regulatory framework at European Union level but also active policies to support of professions, especially in relation to the challenges posed by globalisation and digitisation. The freelancer should be considered in a double dimension: that of professional in the strict sense and that of a small entrepreneur. We therefore need lifelong training, services to promote greater intra-European mobility and greater propensity for internationalisation, a reduction in bureaucratic burdens and easier access to funding. In particular, strong attention should be paid to the impact of digitisation on professional services. On the one hand we can certainly emphasize opportunities, on the other hand, the aspects of employment and quality of the services provided should be carefully assessed. Dear Members, Europe's competitiveness and the preservation of our social, economic and cultural model also pass through the protection of the quality of professional services for the benefit of citizens, enterprises and authorities.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur Mr Danti for his report underlining the fundamental role of professions and the need for high-quality professional services as well as an effective regulatory environment.  Professional services do indeed play a crucial role in Europe’s society and economy and as Mr Danti said, they employ 22% of our labour force. They also account for almost a quarter of the value added in the European Union. That is precisely why we in the Commission have taken such a big interest in them.  But several studies have shown that the European professional services sector is seriously underperforming and its productivity is lagging behind. They conclude that a modernised legal framework could bring as many as 700 000 new jobs to the EU and increase EU GDP by up to 1%. In other words, the same order of magnitude as the EU budget.  This is not a minor matter. This is a call for action that we cannot ignore. We must create the best possible regulatory framework for professional services, a framework that does not restrict professionals’ freedom in an unwarranted fashion, but one that allows them to contribute maximally to the welfare of our society. I trust that this House shares our objective to deliver this framework. Nearly five years ago the Council and Parliament asked the Member States to screen their professional regulation as part of a comprehensive mutual evaluation exercise, foreseen in the revised Professional Qualifications Directive, because even where legislation aims to improve social welfare the resulting rules will not always best succeed.  Indeed, even by the time they are adopted rules can be outdated or inadequate. They can be disproportionate or the accumulation of layers of rules can lead to an overly restrictive legal framework. National legislators may not always take into account the external effects on competitiveness, social welfare and the single market. So constant modernisation of the legal framework governing professional services in the EU is crucial.  We welcome the efforts by Member States since the adoption of the revised Qualifications Directive to increase the transparency of the regulation and assess the substance of the rules in place. This has helped to create a database at EU level offering both an important source of information for professionals and making it easier for them to move.  We continue to work hard to improve the functioning and user-friendliness of that database but sadly, Member States’ substantive assessment of the professional rules in place was often of a poor quality or even absent. Moreover, many failed to grasp this opportunity for reform to improve their regulatory framework, although experience with such reforms in the Italian pharmacy and Polish legal sector, for example, clearly show that removing unnecessary burdens creates benefits for all.  The evaluation showed that there are big differences in the way in which Member States regulate very similar professions. Variance in itself is not a problem. Differences in regulatory approaches can sometimes be the reflection of different circumstances, but there are also instances where the variance does not reflect differences in national specificities or preferences and where the design of the rules could be improved.  To get a better perspective on how restrictive the regulatory framework for a specified profession in a specific country is, we developed the so-called ‘restrictiveness indicator’. This allows us to measure the accumulated burden of different regulatory requirements for some important professional services sectors. It is based on a solid analysis of regulation in place in all Member States. It refines the parameters of the well known and widely used OECD PMR indicator.  Of course, this indicator is only intended to measure the restrictiveness of professional regulation and, as is pointed out in the report, this indicator is not intended to assess whether a restriction can be justified because it pursues a legitimate public interest in a proportionate manner. This is a separate exercise which the Member States have to do in line with the Treaty, but it is still helpful in indicating where Member State regulation is especially restrictive and where they have an interest in examining that regulation more deeply.  Differences in the level of restrictiveness may not be problematic in and of themselves, but they do indicate that other countries might have found other less restrictive ways forward. This could serve as an inspiration. In order to assist the Member States with the removal of specific unjustified restrictions and to identify possibilities for improving the regulatory environment, we have put forward reform recommendations for seven professional services sectors. They are based on the restrictiveness indicator combined with a qualitative assessment. They target those instances where regulation is found to be particularly restrictive.  These reform recommendations are also important in the context of the European Semester exercise, which has addressed the issue of regulation of professions in several instances. While the indicator may not tell the whole story as it is referred to in the report, this does not mean that the rest of this story should not be based on strong evidence. Indeed, the Professional Qualifications Directive reinforced the obligation for Member States to ensure that the restrictions they impose are truly justified and demonstrably proportionate.  Based on the experience with the mutual evaluation exercise, it became clear that Member States may have difficulties in conducting such a proportionality assessment. Also in some cases the readiness to revisit existing regulations seemed limited. The uneven scrutiny of regulation of professions called for a coherent legal framework, so we put forward a proposal for an ex ante proportionality test for new regulations on which trilogues will start at the end of this month. It fully respects Member States’ responsibility for the regulatory decisions they take. It does not impose an obligation of result, it simply proposes a common EU-wide framework to conduct a genuine proportionality assessment before a new or amended regulation is proposed. Finally, these two policy initiatives will complement and strengthen the Commission’s enforcement policy rather than replace it. In this context we take due note of Parliament’s call for infringement proceedings to address discriminatory, unjustified and disproportionate regulation. We stand ready to act to address the issue.  We count on the sustained support of honourable Members to keep the reform of professional services high on the political agenda. It is only with their active commitment that we will be able to unleash the potential of this important sector for the benefit of our citizens.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (DE) Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. First of all, I would like to thank Mr Danti and all the shadow rapporteurs for their excellent cooperation on this very sensitive issue. I believe that the report that is being discussed and voted on today has provided a good basis for entering the so-called service package. Commissioner Vella, I am delighted that you are here this morning. I am sure that Commissioner Bieńkowska will be there herself when we discuss the service package here. The essential principles that should guide the European legislator, as well as the Commission, in the regulation of service professions, require great sensitivity, because, of course, there is a high willingness of the parties involved to give themselves rules, which are often relatively far from the level of professional management. what is being discussed in the European context are gone. That is why, from the outset, I would also ask the European Commission to act with skill, flexibility and sensitivity among the relevant stakeholders in the professions, so as not to unnecessarily smash porcelain, because in principle there is already a willingness and the will to ensure compliance with European law in the profession. occupational regulation, for example, in the self-management of the liberal professions or even in the craft sector, which is not always easy in practice. That is why, in this report, on the start of the service package, we have been guided by the idea that sensible regulation can also provide incentives for competition. I am grateful that the Commission and Parliament have adopted the principle that regulation per se is a mistake. In this respect, we simply have to rely on sensible regulation. I also believe that if the Member States and the Member States and the Professional organisations work closely together, occupational regulation does not have to be a market obstacle, but we just have to make it — unfortunately, we have to be patient for this because things are only slowly evolving — and that the internal market is more likely to succeed if we can do this together accordingly. Thirdly, Commissioner Vella, as you pointed out: in the end, the Commission will not fail to initiate infringement proceedings on a case-by-case basis, because we cannot legislate on all professions simply because very few have opposed the rules of the European internal market. I know that this is uncomfortable for the Commission, but you are facing this task under the Treaties.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (FR) Madam President, first of all I would like to thank Mr Nicola Danti and to welcome his work, his report, which I hope will bring together a large majority. This large majority is gathered because, precisely, we are in a logic of balance and compromise, which takes into account all our main principles, but also tries to anchor ourselves in the reality of economic activity and the reality of consumers throughout the European area. This is not a small feat in a context where we are dealing with a more global climate around the services package, which I find particularly emblematic of the disconnection of a number of the proposals that can be made here with the reality of businesses, SMEs and consumers. Indeed, we are always talking about unjustified barriers, regulatory obstacles, but it would nevertheless be worth remembering that regulation, regulation and obligation meet — if they still exist and if the Commission has done its job correctly — to objectives of the general interest, that these regulations are there to preserve the health and consumer safety, food safety and environmental protection. These are not thin goals and they deserve careful attention before they are obligatory to question them. This is what Nicola Danti's report points out, the need for balance. In this regard, I regret that our Liberal colleagues, once again, are demonstrating this great deregulatory dogmatism by simply removing the reference to those objectives of general interest, which must be the basis of any regulation. I hope this amendment will not pass. I would like to thank Nicola once again for his excellent work and I hope that he will receive a great majority earlier.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President, the current problem in the field of regulated professions is closely related to the issue of protectionism and the disruption of the labour single market, which we have been discussing a lot in our committee in recent months. On the one hand, we have the right of Member States to regulate those professions where they believe that the public interest is required. On the other hand, we have the right of workers to pursue their profession in any Member State. I therefore consider it essential that national regulation of occupations always correspond to the principles of non-discrimination and proportionality. And that the Member State clearly defines the public interest it pursues by regulation. I am pleased that these principles are also highlighted on several occasions in the report presented. As is apparent from the Commission communication to which the report responds, Member States also impose regulatory conditions where we would seek the public interest in vain. However, we could easily identify the protectionist interest in protecting our own regulated market from competition. I would therefore also like to call on the Commission, as guardian of the Treaties, to actively enforce compliance with the principle of non-discrimination and proportionality from the Member States. The basic rules of the European Union are essentially well set out in its Treaties, but the problem is that they are not respected, also because the Commission is insufficiently enforceable from the Member States. As my colleague Schwab said, the infrared will be needed here. Finally, let me thank you for the cooperation of Mr Danti and, in particular, Mr Schwab.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I would like to start by congratulating Mr Danti for excellent work that has been done with the great care for detail and in a very good atmosphere. I believe that today we are taking a step towards achieving our vision of a functioning single market for services, of which professional services are of course a cornerstone. Around 50 million people in Europe are working in these services, so they are extremely important. Too often, regulation in the Member States still operates against this goal, while the evidence shows us that the EU countries that have fewer obstacles to cross-border competition are actually performing much better than the Member States where the restrictions are still in place. We believe that the regulation, at European and national level, of professional services should be proportionate, justified and non-discriminatory. Member States should identify and remove the unjustified regulatory barriers in the interests of the citizens to enable them to benefit from the new professional opportunities. If I made an effort to become a lawyer, a doctor, an architect, whatever, then it’s reasonable to expect to be able to exercise that profession, even outside the walls of my city. We believe that this professionality should not be optional, but impossible to avoid, and that is why that we need transparency and legal clarity. This is the reason I tabled amendment on behalf of my group about it. We have to provide a clear legal reference for Member States, in line with the pivotal principles of non-discrimination and proportionality. But even with this remark, I believe that we are today a bit closer to our vision of a functioning single market. I am very happy about this.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: for the GUE/NGL Group. — First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur for the work done on the report. Some positive elements appear in the report, such as recognition of the importance of regulated professions for the service sector or innovation. But I have a problem with the basic principle of the prescription. In fact, I believe that the Member States' established obligation to notify the Commission of what changes they have made to their national arrangements within regulated professions is directly contrary to the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality. Each country must, for itself, be able to determine what prerequisites and qualifications must be fulfilled for the exercise of a particular profession. Regulation of certain occupations is necessary to ensure protection of public capture, high consumer protection and high quality of service. While I support the system of mutual recognition of diplomas and qualifications, I believe that adjusting the conditions for the exercise of regulated professions must remain fully within the competence of the Member States. I do not want the Commission to dictate to Czech applicants for the post of attorney the length of practice or to prescribe the need for education for Czech medics, etc. I will recommend my political faction to abstain from voting on the proposal. (The Speaker agreed to answer the question posed by lifting the blue card (Article 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Richard SULÍK
text: the question asked by picking up the blue card. — Thank you very much. Mr. Maštálka, on a number of things you can definitely agree with. These are just things to discuss, and I am a little sorry that you want to stay here because I felt that there was a very broad agreement here. And maybe a lot of things we could discuss. And my question is, why did you not participate in any or essentially no negotiation where we could have just discussed this in peace? (interrupted by Madam President and continued in English)

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: answer to the question raised by raising a blue card. — I may not have participated in the negotiations at which you did not notice me, but I made my suggestions as is customary. So it's no surprise that I give such a recommendation to my faction, and I have undergone many negotiations even within the faction.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — I contribute to congratulating the rapporteur, in fact, for his good work, and I believe that the right of European citizens to work in any Member State is one of the four fundamental freedoms of the European Union. Freedom of movement for professionals in the single market is a practical example of the functioning of the European socio-economic model. Of course, the regulation of professional activities is an essential condition for ensuring the quality of public services provided and protecting the public interest, and therefore the quality of education must be a very important priority for all Member States. As the rapporteur rightly pointed out, the experience of implementing the directive is not unequivocally encouraging. We have many examples where professionals wishing to be employed in another Member State face logically inexplicable obstacles: administrative requirements, long procedures or simply an open obstacle to obtaining the necessary information. We, the Group of the Greens, supported the proportionality test proposed by the Commission for the new professional requirements. It was supposed to be a good tool to solve the problems faced by citizens. Unfortunately, it is regrettable that Member States do not always boast of applying transparent professional requirements. This can be confirmed by many people working abroad. The document under discussion is an excellent opportunity to remind Member States of their commitment to enabling all European citizens to employ according to their qualifications. I would like to point out that the principle of good governance requires, first of all, to address the gaps in the implementation of the existing regulation, especially since the problems arise mainly from the scope of implementation of the provisions of the directive, which the Commission must carry out in its day-to-day activities, and therefore the need for to welcome the Commission's ambitions that have just been expressed to tackle these loopholes.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, good morning to you and the 25 brave Members prepared to turn up this morning. Mairead, if you are able to pronounce the name of the next speaker on the list to their satisfaction, I think I’ll buy you a drink. This report calls for yet more unnecessary interference in the field of professional services. Therefore it goes without saying that I cannot support this initiative. This is yet another area where the Commission has pushed forward with their political agenda and has introduced more harmonisation. We would not be here talking about this this morning if there was a great appetite for such actions around Europe. The fact that six Member States did not submit their national action plans within the deadline given by the Commission speaks for itself. Such statistics do not lead me to believe that a harmonised approach to this subject is the correct approach or that it is even welcome. The aim of opening up professions in order to create more jobs and improve the economy is honourable. Very few people would disagree with this. However, I believe that Member States are more than capable of carrying this out themselves, if and when it is necessary. It is certainly not for the Commission to become involved with. Member States should be free to act as they wish, as will benefit their citizens, as they are in the best position to say what works best for their citizens and their economies. The United Kingdom already has a strong history of trustworthy professionals, and we certainly do not need the European Union’s interference in order to continue this proud tradition.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Madam Troszczynski, for two minutes. Mr Agnew, you are in remarkably good form this morning. I am happy to see that, it brightens up the Chamber; not something we normally see from that side of the House, if I may boldly say.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this text concerns me in several ways: firstly, the continued expansion of the European Commission's coercive powers to the detriment of the Member States. One wonders where it intends to stop and whether we, as elected Members, will ever be able to stop it; secondly, the new indicator of restrictivity, a real dematerialised and technocratic tool which will in the future be convinced — an essential argument in favour of the imposition of sanctions by the Commission, despite all of the promises that can be made to you today; thirdly, the expansion of professional recognition which, however, could be positive on a case-by-case basis, but which is in fact terribly destabilizing on the scale envisaged, whether from an economic, social or cultural point of view; fourth, the systematically presented character as any idea of national preference, even with regard to those regulated professions, which are nevertheless described by the rapporteur himself as strategic for the general balance of the Member States; finally, the ransacking of regulated professions is very much underway. The technocratic apprentices in Brussels, inventors of all kinds of clues, should focus on their calamitous record and realize that these measures are not adapted to certain Member States, which often have much more to lose than gain. I would like to add to hon. members who are softening these policies that they should be more concerned about ensuring the public interest rather than giving up to the federalist drift that brings us closer to the coast every day and a collective sinking. The ENL Group, which I represent this morning, will oppose the adoption of this report in the vote, for reasons of obvious common sense. (She agreed to answer a question “blue card” (Article 162 (8) of the Regulation)

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: “Blue card” question. — Dear colleague, it seems that once again you are not representing the Europe of nations, but a nationalist Europe. You know, what you said about the models applied by each member country on this subject — what is your opinion on the models that all Member States of the European Union can apply on the subject we are debating this morning?

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: answer “blue card”. — Listen, each country has its own rules, its own standards and reacts according to its own interests and, in general, when we talk about standardization or harmonisation in this Chamber, it is often harmonization and levelling from the bottom. Therefore, I believe that each Member State is in a position to legislate in accordance with its own interests and that will always be my objective and, in any case, my axis of defence in this Chamber.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Madam President, these efforts by the European Union to harmonise professional qualifications are the next step towards the creation of a federal superstate, but when you have got disastrous youth unemployment figures, such as in Greece and Italy, what else can you do but try and liberalise the market and give people, young people, the opportunity to move to where the jobs are? Worldwide university rankings consistently put the United Kingdom in the top tier. No other countries, other than Germany and Sweden, come anywhere near, and there is a very big distance between them. But no one seems to have considered in the European Union, in the Commission, the threat posed by 400 fake universities in China and 300 in India, all of them issuing degrees and other qualifications which are creating real distortions and real threats in the market. Under the freedom of movement pillar, this particular directive and this proposal are going to create a brand new opportunity for European-based criminal gangs, and I can see some real problems coming down the line, and I would like to see them addressed.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Mr Szejnfeld, exceptionally you have speaking time now, but you did want to ask a question of Ms James. Because we are all in great humour this morning in the Chamber I am going to allow you to ask your question before you speak. Ms James, if you accept of course.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Madam President, no, there is no point. I do not wish to give another MEP unneeded and unnecessary speaking time.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Mr Szejnfeld, there’s your answer, but perhaps you could incorporate the comments into your speech, which is now for one-and-a-half minutes.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Madam President! It's hard, I'm going to have to give up some of my time, so that I can address Ms. James's speech. Namely, I am amazed at the thesis that closing countries, closing markets, closing competitions — that is opening up to young people, that is giving them a new opportunity. Well, it's just the opposite, which is why I strongly support this dossier we're talking about today. The topic is very important: the market for services generates 71% of GDP in the European Union, 68% of jobs. It shows what a power it is, actually it is a pillar, the foundation of the common market. But in this market for services is not happening well precisely because of regulations on regulated professions. It's just enough to say that years have passed and Directive 2005/36/EC to today by many countries is not implemented, including 6 countries have not presented their national action plans at all. It is also evidenced by numerous regulations. These are, please, tens of thousands of regulations, tens of thousands of regulations, on the scale of the European Union The very fact that 1200 national bodies deal with this topic shows how confusing and complicated everything is. 5500 professions in Europe are regulated. That is why I support all these requests and proposals to the European Commission and to the bodies of the European Union to introduce deregulation of professions in the European Union, harmonisation and control of the activities of the countries in this regard.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: – Madam President I wasn’t going to start by making a comment about one of the previous speakers but I think I will. I am absolutely forced to. The individual who just spoke – Ms James, a former leader of UKIP – talking about her interest in higher education and young people in my country beggars belief. Young people in my country are now going to be denied access to working in another EU country. And as for her interest in higher education, well … Higher education is about to lose money in terms of our research budgets, so I am sorry Madam President but I had to say something against that speaker. Mr Danti’s report, however, is something to be welcomed. Too many people in our European Union today are denied the basic right to use their professional qualification in another Member State. It is disgraceful that, in 2018, those people cannot do something that is part of their fundamental rights. Having this debate today is therefore absolutely pivotal, so that people will be able to realise the potential that is there, so that Europeans’ talent is realised, and so that we can be successful in creating the knowledge economy that we all want to see.  (Applause)

name: Daniel DALTON
text: – Madam President, I too would like to thank Mr Danti for his report because it is clear we need more political commitment to remove barriers to services. This Parliament has said that repeatedly, including in the report I did on non-tariff barriers in 2016. We often hear that restriction is essential, but what that really means is we want to stop other Europeans from offering services. It is discriminatory and it is against the principles of the treaties. Mutual recognition is at the heart of many aspects of the single market: it is what makes the single market unique. Yet it is under threat more than anywhere in professional services. From hairdressers to ski instructors, we’re all aware of, frankly, ridiculous examples of protectionism that are dressed up as protecting the public. They do no such thing. Consumers pay more and get worse services, Europeans are denied employment opportunities, new businesses never develop, and as a continent we struggle to innovate. We need more honest effort to reduce barriers in professional services which are the biggest global growth area, and we need to stop discriminating against EU citizens. Now the UK may not be part of this in the future, but Europe still needs a true internal market in services to thrive. (Applause)

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: – Madam President, 71% of European GDP and 68% of total employment come from services. Regulated professionals account for 22% of all workers. With such numbers, it is shocking and unacceptable that, in many Member States, the free movement of services is still not respected and promoted. It is equally shocking that Member States, instead of moving towards harmonised regulations on professionals, continue to invent new national barriers to prevent free movement and the equal treatment of all EU citizens. I am here to tell you that a Czech professional is just as good as a German, French or any other professional. We must deregulate where restrictions are unjustified and harmonise where they are. We cannot continue to allow economic protectionism within the single market.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: Madam President, the profound impact of the way in which professions are regulated on the economy of the European Union is not sufficient reason for Member States to lose control of what is the exclusive competence of each of them. This debate is not new, and it is worthwhile to say again that the European Commission should no longer attempt to appropriate those powers. We already saw it with the proportionality test, when the proposal made by the European Commission was rejected by the Employment Committee. Proportionality of regulations in professions cannot be reviewed beforehand by the Commission. That is why there is the Court of Justice of the European Union, which does so on a case-by-case basis in specific situations and not on a general basis. We must get out of our mind that regulation of professions is an economic, market issue. These rules need to be proportionate and non-discriminatory, but it is the Member States and the Court of Justice who have to ensure that this is the case.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: — Madam President, by introducing proportionality checks on regulated professions, the Commission is making a mistake on the substance and the law. On the substance, first, because its ideological bias is not underpinned by any credible economic analysis. In fact, successive waves of deregulation have systematically resulted in a deterioration in service and employment. Regulated professions will experience the same fate, while some, such as in the field of law, are already experiencing a considerable deterioration in their conditions of practice. Secondly, on the law, because these regulations fall within the competence of the Member States, under both the case-law of the Court of Justice of the European Union and the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. The Member States therefore have to justify themselves all the less because these professions fulfil tasks in the general interest that require a high level of qualification.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, common interests such as the protection of the environment, consumer protection and public health are safeguarded by rules and regulations for professions, demanding specific professional qualifications to practice an activity. However, because these rules are not harmonised at EU level, their standards vary between Member States. The role played by the professions is a vital component of the European economy, upholding our common objectives. Unfortunately, as Commissioner Vella pointed out, this area is underperforming.  The Professional Qualifications Directive is important as it upholds the fundamental EU right to the free movement of labour by enabling the free movement of professionals. It sets out the rules for automatic recognition for a number of professions, based on harmonised minimum training requirements, a general system for the recognition of professional qualifications, a system for the automatic recognition of professional experience, and a system of cross-border provision of services in the context of regulated professions. In 2013, we introduced Article 59 of this Directive, which provides for transparency and a mutual evaluation exercise for all regulated professions in Member States, whether they are regulated on the basis of national rules or are harmonised at EU level. Unfortunately, not all the provisions of Article 59 have yet been fully implemented by Member States, even after the passing of the deadline. This is something that needs to be rectified because if we, as individual politicians, miss deadlines, we will probably be named and shamed, and possibly fined and penalised, yet some of these Member States can get away with applying different rules to us. I think it is time for action. This is a good proposal by Mr Danti and Commissioner Vella.

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: — Mr President, it is certainly not an easy thing to combine national practices and interests with this important European idea, where the competence and skills levels are raised, the movement of people, the functioning of the internal market and the competitiveness that arises from all these issues. Competitiveness arises specifically from the high level of competence and the mobility of citizens. In this respect, the rapporteur Danti has managed to produce a very balanced report. Indeed, frankly, it is shameful and inexcusable that the Member States have not yet implemented a professional quality directive and therefore it is very important that the implementation now has as much transparency as possible and try to achieve comparability and common common the objective specifically because of the increasing European competitiveness and human rights based on the level of competence.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Madam President! The reform of professional services makes a good impression in the spirit of the EU Treaties. The Directive is balanced overall and will strengthen the European Union's economy. That is why I can and will agree with her. I would like to draw attention to another problem in this context: intra-European migration as a result of the EU's eastward enlargement and the euro crisis is far greater than originally assumed. Brexit, in particular, was a clear warning call for the EU. After Brexit, migration flows will increasingly arrive in the metropolitan areas of Western Europe, which are already severely affected by migration, and my city will also be affected. As a result of migration, internal migration and the unresolved euro crisis, real estate prices and rents have already been going through the ceiling in recent years. This development is expected to intensify, including through well-intentioned reports such as those here. In other reports, such as the Posting of Workers Directive, we already find hidden protectionist measures today. Although none of the so-called pro-Europeans wants to admit that migration — that is, European internal migration — also has problems, but support for protectionist measures shows exactly this. We just have to deal with this here honestly.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Recognition of professional qualifications is one way to promote mobility and competitiveness within the EU. The revision of the directive, which took place in 2013, has gone in the right direction. The obligation of Member States to notify the Commission of an overview of their regulated professions and the possibility of States to evaluate each other's national requirements also contribute to the breakdown of unwarranted obstacles. In the framework of breaking down barriers, it is important to make professions easier to compare with each other across states. Improving the database of all regulated professions would contribute to this. The obligation of the State to assess the proportionality of introduced requirements before adopting new regulation is also beneficial. However, this assessment tends to be carried out differently in the Member States. In order to really eliminate unreasonable requirements and prevent protectionism, there is a need to ensure the same practice in all states. I therefore support the proposal for a directive that would establish a uniform framework for assessing the adequacy of national requirements. A common framework should help ensure that the regulations being prepared are not a mere formality. At the same time, this would strengthen trust between Member States. I would also welcome the Professional Card to be extended beyond the current 5 professions for which it is applied, to keep up with the development of digital technologies and eliminate administrative obstacles.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Madam President! Thank you to Mr. Danti for making a really good and balanced report. The EU single market with free movement of both goods and persons is undoubtedly a good one. It's valuable and it has generated growth and development. This is also true for the services sector, where consumers and businesses are really benefiting from the fact that we have removed a whole range of unnecessary barriers. But when it comes to setting out requirements for, for example, what qualifications people need to do a job, then we Social Democrats think it is not the consideration of the total free market that needs to be at the forefront. We believe that the single market works very best when we regulate market forces. It also applies to the professions regulated by law. We social democrats don't just want regulation for the sake of regulation, limitations for the sake of restriction. We believe it is completely in its place that the consideration of the patient in the hospital, the consumer in everyday life and our all nature of the same is allowed to take precedence. In turn, we wholeheartedly support the fact that when regulation is made, including in the Member States, there must be full transparency. It has to be clear to everyone what demands it is we make of each other. We therefore also support the need to make national action plans. However, it is absolutely central to us Socialists that those who meet regulation in their everyday lives are also involved in work. This applies, in particular, to the professional organisations. I would like to thank you very much to Mr. Danti to ensure that exactly these considerations are included in the report so that we can achieve balance and have a good and functioning internal market.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: — Madam President, the regulation of professional qualifications strengthens the single market and labour mobility and therefore strengthens the effective European Union. It must be remembered that the Bologna process has enabled convergence in academic qualifications, along with the European Qualifications Framework, which allows, by way of example, a young Portuguese graduate, to be recognised in another European Member State. But this convergence is incomplete. The biggest problem is the specialised professions requiring recognition by professional bodies, which is why I advocate creating a European framework of professional qualifications that harmonises the requirements of work activity. I would also like to argue, Commissioner, that we strengthen, when they exist, and that we create, in non-existent cases, the European federations of professional bodies, which will allow, also by way of example, that a young Portuguese person who is a member of the Portuguese Order of Psychologists in Portugal, will automatically be recognised by way of an example. capacity and which is also automatically recognised by the Order of Psychologists, for example in the United Kingdom, allowing effective labour mobility also in specialized professions.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: — If we want to continue to break down barriers in the internal market, one of the areas must also be professional mobility. The common procedure at Union level should remove unreasonable obstacles while guaranteeing the high quality of services provided. Professional regulation is an important tool for public interest protection, patient safety and consumer protection. I agree that transparency and comparability of qualifications for regulated occupations is essential, and that the main measure of comparisons should be quality of services, not simple numbers. All stakeholders, headed by social partners, should be more involved in the consultation on professional regulation. It is only possible to strengthen confidence, which is absolutely crucial to the functioning of the internal market. But in addition to education and skills development, we also think of how to provide professionals with adequate conditions for the exercise of their profession within and without labour mobility, i.e. domestic labor market.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, regulation on professional services and qualifications is important for the internal market. I'm surprised by the position of some colleagues who show they would actually block. On the contrary — free movement of citizens, and especially young people who are preparing in certain areas of services, to be able to practice in any Member State — in fact, that means that we are a European Union and an internal market, that is what it means. I congratulate my colleague Danti on the report, on the balance, very many good amendments. Thank you also to the Commissioner. And I think it is important to understand that the effective and efficient implementation of this report leads, on the one hand, to competitiveness, better services, lower prices and better service quality for consumers. And I also very much believe that, on the contrary, if we vote on this regulation today and implement it, it will lead to the elimination of unjustified and disproportionate discrimination, especially for young professionals. I support the report and hope it will be voted on.

name: Milan ZVER
text: — Thank you for saying, Honourable Madam Chairman, Dear Mr. Commissioner. I, too, congratulate my colleague Dani on a job well done. It's a very sensitive topic, as we know it. We don't have many directives in the field of education and training, this is one of the few that tries to somehow standardize professional standards across Europe. We have very different systems in the Member States. We've heard earlier of Mr. Schwab saying that in Germany they have their own traditional system where professional associations set professional standards and the like. We have some members where state officials govern these kinds of tasks. So, we certainly need a more comparable system at the level of the European Union. In 2008, we adopted the European Qualification Framework, which is still under-implemented in Member States, and the like. However, it is necessary to be very attentive here, it is about sovereign policies of national states, it is necessary to strike a balance between national sovereignty and regulation by the European Union.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, I welcome this very important report which highlights that high-quality professional services and an effective regulatory environment are of utmost importance for preserving the EU’s economic, social and cultural model and for boosting the competitiveness of the European Union.  I would like to recall that regulated professions, which represent up to 22% of the labour force in the EU and cover many crucial sectors, constitute a significant element in the economy of the Member States, and rules on regulated professions are usually imposed to ensure the protection of general interest objectives such as public health, consumer protection or public security. Indeed in many cases the regulation is justified on the above-mentioned grounds.  However for a regulation to be fair for professionals and to ensure mobility within the European Union, the latter has to fully respect the principles of non-discrimination and proportionality, and the Member States must be transparent about the rules they put forward.  I conclude by stressing that irrespective of the model applied by each country, where restrictions may be removed or be rendered more proportionate, these tasks should be carried out for the benefit of European citizens.

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: Madam President, Commissioner. A very clear commitment to the internal market and to the four freedoms — this, of course, includes the free movement of services. And yet — which is why this discussion is so important today — there are areas that cannot simply be subject to the free market economy. For me, this is the whole area of services of general interest and, in particular, health care. That is why I am delighted with the speeches we have had today. We need regulation in certain areas, we need harmonisation, but also from the point of view of consumer protection, transparency and the prevention of distortion of competition. I believe that this paper is a good, balanced paper that we can fully endorse. But I would like to make one more comment: if I am afraid of intra-European migration flows here, then the answer to this cannot be that I stop this free movement of services, but we must look at the roots of this intra-European migration and must not be allowed in the areas of Structural support or cohesion support should use the austerity pin to the extent that we are selling people from the regions in which they would actually like to live and work.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: — Madam President, the economic crisis, which has been plaguing Europe, and especially Greece for many years, has significantly affected the smooth exercise of many professions. A large number of them have been abandoned, others are on the verge of disappearance, many workers have lost their jobs, and especially young scientists, when they finally manage to find a job, it usually has nothing to do with the subject of their science. This is a situation that needs to be addressed and a solution found. Young people must acquire the necessary qualifications in order to pursue certain professions, particularly the regulated professions, they must acquire the experience and skills, and all this must be the responsibility and responsibility of each State. Because it is the state that knows the problems it faces and how it should resolve them. Then each Member State, in cooperation with the other Member States and the European Union, will create a framework which can then be implemented in all the countries of Europe.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Members for this interesting debate. It is clear that we share the common aim of creating an effective legal environment so that we can ensure high—quality professional services. The mutual evaluation exercise was an important first step, but it also showed that much work remains to be done. Analytical tools like the Restrictiveness Indicator can support us in this effort by pointing out possible instances of inadequate regulation or over-regulation. It is then for the Member States to examine the justification for these restrictions and to check whether there are alternative, less harmful measures. The proposed proportionality test will also be a key instrument for preventing the adoption of disproportionate professional rules. The Commission thanks the House once again for your support for its policy initiative and looks forward to working with you to create competitive and high-quality professional services.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, at the end of this debate, let me in the meantime thank all the shadow rapporteurs in this report and all those who are. intervened in this morning's debate. At the end of this debate, I would like to emphasize one word: balance — has been underlined by multiple interventions. We are dealing with a market that has very often been perhaps the most closed of all European markets, sometimes not only nationally but also locally. The professional has often been singled out as the one who operates on the territory, on a local reality, and we need — and this is the European directives that ask for it, and the work we are doing We reaffirm in this report — to expand intra-European mobility of the professions, give greater opportunities for inter-European mobility to young people, improve the quality of services, increase the supply of the internal EU and competition. But at the same time, we also need to ensure that national regulations guarantee proportionality, are proportional for access to these professions, to protect citizens, to protect the public and consumer protection authorities. However, at this final stage, I would like to emphasize one aspect. I believe, Madam President, Commissioner and ladies and gentlemen, that the competition will not be among European professionals. The digital market is opening our market to the world: now in the world you can find online platforms offering professional services from all over the world, barriers have been broken down. And then I think that the qualifying point we want to work on and that we have included in this report is that we need stronger, more capable professionals, more able to stay on the market international, and this is done with training, with digitization, with collaboration between the system national professional and within a European system. This is what we have in front of us. The challenge is difficult, it is a challenge on which we will continue to work and, I believe, with the cooperation of the Commission and with the approval of the next directive on proportionality testing, we will have the elements to ensure that European professionals have the characteristics and ability to compete in the global world.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place shortly. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: in writing. – The harmonisation of minimum training requirements of regulated professions (such as doctors, nurses, teachers and others) from 2005 was an important step in order to facilitate the free movement of those specialists across the EU. There is about 5 5000 regulated professions in the Union, standing for approximately 22% of all labour force, which were touched by this piece of legislation. Nevertheless, until now, the full clarity and transparency on the different national requirements, exceeding the minimum harmonisation, have not been achieved. Therefore, the Member States along with the European Commission should improve the overview of the further country-specific requirements and to develop a better comparing system in the publicly accessible database (Regulated Professions Database). I acknowledge the need to protect the national consumers and recipients of services. However, the Commission shall take action and launch infringement procedures to prevent adopting any kind of discriminatory or disproportionate laws that have or will appear at national states’ level. Furthermore, I welcome the EC’s recognition of need to evaluate the influence of modern technologies and digitalisation on professional services to secure a high level of competitiveness.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: in writing. — There are more than 5500 regulated professions in the Union, with clear differences between Member States as regards the restrictiveness of the solutions adopted. The European Commission's research shows that Member States have trouble assessing their proportionality. This is important, because these occupations account for 22% of the workforce in all branches of the economy. It is also of concern that not all provisions of Directive 2005/36/EC have so far been fully implemented by Member States, despite the deadline. The European Commission has recently undertaken a number of measures aimed at positive effects in the area of regulated professions and on the creation of an interactive map that enables citizens to check the requirements for access to professions across the Union, or the restriction indicator regulations in force in the Member States. Nevertheless, as the rapporteur rightly notes, a comprehensive analysis of their impact should be subject not only to quantitative but also to qualitative assessment. The European Commission should focus in the near term on the impact of scientific progress, technological innovation and digitalisation on regulated professions. The developments create new opportunities for the representatives of these professions, but they also present challenges for the EU labour market. Thus, we should start looking at how to adapt existing regulatory regulations for regulated professions to the technological and social changes that will affect us in the coming years.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. – There is no doubt that regulated professions represent an important element in our economy. Therefore, the overview of national systems of regulation of professions and of proportionality assessments conducted by Member States is very important. The report highlights the quality of professional services and the fact that this is of paramount importance in preserving the European economic, social and cultural model. It identifies the main aspects of the implementation of Article 59 of Directive 2005/36/EC and recalls the importance of professional regulations in relation to the protection of legitimate public interests. The report also indicates specific areas in which Member States are invited to consider improvements in their regulation. It is also important that the Commission has developed a new indicator on the restrictiveness of professional regulation, which may be more effective. In the future, we should monitor the implementation of the recommendations. If necessary, we will be able to measure and address the remaining barriers – a point also underlined in the report. To this end we should also continue to reflect on the impact of scientific progress, innovation and digitalisation on regulated professions.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on Nigeria (2018/2513(RSP)).

name: Tunne KELAM
text: author. – Madam President, 30 million Christians live in the northern part of Nigeria, where peace and stability have been dramatically undermined by ongoing attacks, murders and kidnappings by the Islamist Boko Haram group since 2009. During this period, more than 20 000 people, belonging to different denominations, have been killed and 2 million have been displaced.  According to the NGO Open Doors, two-thirds of the 3 000 Christians killed in the world in one year, up to November 2017, met violent deaths in Nigeria. The latest attack happened in Omoku, with 14 killed and many wounded after a New Year’s Eve church service. I urgently call on the Nigerian authorities to increase efforts to protect the Christian community and end violence there. Decisive efforts are needed to defend citizens’ rights to worship freely and in safety.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. – Madam President, Nigeria is beset by multiple challenges, from geographical sectarian divisions to fighting brutal jihadi terrorism. Given its huge natural oil resources, nearly 200 million in population and strong economic position in Africa, it should be a role model for the rest of the continent. Whilst we are familiar with the tragic kidnapping of the Chibok schoolgirls, the majority of whom are still missing, we must remind ourselves too of the thousands of others that have been killed and the 1.4 million that have been displaced by Boko Haram, a brutal terrorist organisation, since its inception in 2009.  The campaign against Boko Haram has had some success under President Buhari. However, attacks persist and there is still a lack of understanding about the group’s underlying support base and where it gets its funding from. Corruption remains, of course, one of the biggest challenges for Nigeria, placed 136 out of 175 countries in the Transparency International index. Buhari’s government needs to do far more to investigate and prosecute those guilty of corruption.  None of the challenges facing Nigeria are easy to overcome. We see in our own countries, even with the benefit of much greater resources at our disposal, the difficulties in defeating international terrorism. The EU must therefore continue to extend its offers of support and help, and to share our experience, in conjunction with the African Union, in supporting Nigeria.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: author. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, yesterday is the news of the abduction of two Americans and two Canadians in northern Nigeria, kidnapping in which their carers were killed Nigerians. This episode testifies to the insecurity prevailing in the north, with Boko Haram continuing to operate. We must recognise President Buhari's efforts in the fight against terrorism. It is a difficult commitment, against a cleverly fierce enemy. We condemned ethnic conflicts opposing transhumant herders and sedentarized farmers in the north of the country. The recursiveness of such interethnic conflicts is a sign that demographic pressure requires a change of economic model. We call on the Nigerian government to encourage mediation from below, so that these conflicts cease, and to define economic policies suitable for population growth as soon as possible. There remain pockets of violation on the human rights side that concern us and we call on the government to commit to respect for dignity and human rights throughout the country.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: Author. — The bloody conflict in Nigeria between nomadic farmers and land-based farmers is a conflict over scarcity, a conflict over drought. It's about the climate. People are forced to look for fertile land in the south with their livestock, while others have their plants and crops. If we in Europe want to understand this and interfere, we must not simplify it into a religious conflict between Muslims and Christians. Because then we do exactly the same thing that is happening in Nigeria, where politicians use the difference in religion to give this battle a different connotation. If we are looking for conflict resolution, we must recognise that we are dealing here with a climate problem, with a problem between two lifestyles, with a scarcity problem. Another issue that the Greens call attention to when it comes to human rights, conflicts and Nigeria is the situation in the Niger Delta. The role of oil and oil emultinationals in Nigeria, in cooperation with a corrupt government, continues to destabilise the country further. It is therefore up to us and Europe to at least bring our multinationals to justice - and I am thinking in particular of Shell - to ensure that justice is brought to the people of the Niger Delta. We can do something about stabilising Nigeria, namely calling on our multinationals and not simplifying conflicts into religious debates.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: author. — Madam President, I would prefer to talk about what is not exactly reflected in the resolution. Ladies and gentlemen, Nigeria is the largest economy on the African continent, with large reserves of oil and gas, yet 80% of its population lives in poverty and wealth is concentrated in very few hands. Most oil extraction is in the hands of European companies and many of them are reported for human rights violations. For example, Shell, for complicity in human rights violations against the Ogoni people; Shell and Eni, for international corruption — trial being held in Italy — or Eni, for example, environmental damage caused by the oil pipeline explosion in 2010. Most groups in this Parliament have not seen it pertinent to mention — coincidences of life — the responsibility of European multinationals for the violation of human rights in Nigeria, precisely in an urgent resolution on human rights; let us not be messing up any business! The economic interests of multinationals and their complicit governments are pushing people to flee Nigeria. Thousands risk their lives on migration routes to the European Union and are victims of slavery and ill-treatment. Nigerian women suffer sexual exploitation both on the road to Europe and within our borders. While we plunder Nigeria's natural resources, we build walls and externalize borders to repel the consequences of our plunder; or we open a trust fund for our alms for Africa instead of changing our economic and geo-strategic policies, which is what we would have to do. No more alms, but to be consistent with our policies.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: author. – Madam President, Nigerians have been suffering from increased violence caused by economic and political tensions between ethnic and religious groups, but they are all fighting over scarce resources. Many farmers and pastoralists have lost their lives and property. At the same time, the population is suffering from brutal attacks. Boko Haram has attacked Muslims, Christians and people of all faiths indiscriminately and, particularly terribly, has kidnapped and raped innocent young girls.  Today we urge the Nigerian Government, together with international partners, to increase efforts to bring terrorism and violence to a halt, to protect the rights of all citizens and to take action to resolve the devastating intercommunal conflicts. Effective tackling of corruption and ensuring a more even distribution of resources should benefit all Nigerians, and, in fighting terror, it is essential that state security forces respect human rights.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Madam President! Freedom of religion is a fundamental freedom and a fundamental human right, and we must always respond where it is violated. Nigeria is home to the largest number of Christians in the region, because almost half of its 186 million inhabitants are Christians. We know the example of girls, nearly half of whom have not yet returned to their home, who have been kidnapped in Chibok. Attacks by Islamist groups on Christians, kidnappings, kidnappings of nuns, youths, priests, volunteers, and attacks on Christian organizations, but also on people who participate in religious practices. It seems to me that the international community should respond here to refrain, regardless of the fact that often also the basis of economic existence may be an excuse to inspire such situations. We want to call for more pressure, among other things, in the framework of a permanent political dialogue with Nigeria — in terms of the Cotonou Agreement — on human rights and the principles of democracy, in order for Nigeria to meet its obligation to protect those living on its territory.

name: Neena GILL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, like many other countries in Africa, Nigeria is a prime example of a country that should be rich but in reality is poor. It is Africa’s largest oil producer, yet more than half of Nigerian people live on less than two dollars a day. The demographic explosion means scarce resources come under pressure and fuel conflict. This is not some faraway doom scenario. Last year hundreds of shepherds were killed or disappeared in violent clashes. Meanwhile, the impact of terror committed by Boko Haram continues to be felt. The EU as a whole, and the UK in particular, have particular interests at stake in the country, whether it is managing migration flows or sealing lucrative business deals after Brexit, but these agendas will not get anywhere unless underlying problems in Nigeria are addressed: corruption, inequality and inter-ethnic tension. So my question to the Commissioner is the following: what measures are we taking, as part of our aid to Nigeria, to help tackle these root causes? Do you agree that close cooperation and coordination with the UK after Brexit are necessary in order to make sure we are not going on different strands?

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Madam President, the situation in Nigeria is of extreme violence. There are more than 2 million internally displaced persons, most of whom do not have access to food, home, education or health care. Women and girls suffer rape and sexual exploitation at the hands of Boko Haram, but also by members of security groups, police and soldiers. Hundreds of thousands of Nigerians and Nigerians have left the country in recent months, fleeing this situation of violence and the situation of poverty and lack of the most basic rights. On their way to Europe many have been trapped in those detention camps in Libya, which is funded by the European Union, where they are tortured and enslaved. And what was the solution? To give them asylum in Europe, as set out in the Geneva Convention and the International Treaties? Well, no: deport them; that was the solution. More than two thousand Nigerians and Nigerians have been deported from Libya to Nigeria. Take them out of the violence in Libya to get them back into the violence they fled from in Nigeria. Anything is worth them before opening legal and safe avenues to Europe. Anything already.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, mismanagement of public resources and endemic corruption is having a direct and massive impact on the enjoyment of basic rights by Nigerians, about 54% of whom live in conditions of extreme poverty. Considering that Nigeria has been ranked 136 out of 175 countries in terms of perception of corruption, Nigerian authorities must strengthen measures to tackle corrupt practices, as there is a dangerous link between corruption and terrorism. Those threats are pushing the country towards regressive steps. As affirmed by President Buhari, corruption has been largely responsible for previous failures to end the Boko Haram insurgency. The international community has improved its support for the Nigerian Government’s efforts to fight the Boko Haram threat by increasing assistance. However, if the Nigerian Government fails to tackle corruption, all efforts to end violence will be trivial and a huge amount of the resources supplied will be lost. Worse, our money will fuel an evil system.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: — Talking about the situation in Nigeria and not talking about religion, or not talking about Christianity, is a very strange situation, and I would like to condone what Mrs. Sargentini said here, because christians, this is that group that has been in Nigeria for quite a long time. He's under great pressure, after all, take how many dozens of Christians have died in the last few years. How many dozens of Christians were murdered. Take how many dozens of Christians have been kidnapped and how many dozens of Christian women have been raped. We're not saying this is Nigeria's main problem. Nigeria has other problems, a malfunctioning civil service, huge corruption and other things you mentioned here. But why don't colleagues mention the group of Christians who live there? We have nothing to be ashamed of. Our tradition stands down to Christianity, which is why there is a need to call on the Nigerian government to do something about this.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the growing interethnic conflicts in the middle belt region between shepherds and farmers are only the last element of concern in Nigeria, torn apart by Boko Haram terrorist offensive. The intervention of the Nigerian government to ensure shared management of economic and natural resources must be absolutely immediate. The European Union, as well as condemning acts of extermination and ethnic cleansing, must call on the UN to investigate what is happening in Nigeria. The European Union's intervention towards the Nigerian government must be strong to ratify the African Charter on Democracy, which is necessary to guarantee free elections and to combat corruption rampant. Nigeria is Africa's most populous country and will soon become the third most populous country in the world. Europe must continue to support the country through long-term and short-term measures, such as the package for the reconstruction of the Borno State, which was devastated by Boko Haram. But Commissioner, this is not enough because it is precisely on sharing the commitment to guarantee human rights that the European Union is playing in Africa.

name: David COBURN
text: – Madam President, over the last few years, the Islamic terrorist organisation Boko Haram has killed more than 20 000 people, many of them Christians. Thousands of women and children were enslaved and raped, and according to the International Criminal Court, there are reasonable grounds to believe the Boko Haram may have committed crimes against humanity. A majority in this Parliament wants, and I quote, ‘to monitor the situation in Nigeria to ensure that EU funding is spent effectively’. This is a very weak and naive position. Nigeria should be an extremely wealthy nation – that is how the British Empire left it. We left it wealthy.  Why are we giving EU taxpayers’ money to a country which is one of the most corrupt nations on earth? Why are we still giving European humanitarian aid to a government that is completely unable or unwilling to stop these atrocities? The EU does not need to fund this type of failed state, nor do we need a European External Action Service to follow up on the situation in countries like Nigeria. I suppose the American President might unfortunately have a word for that, but fortunately not here. It is up to the nation-state, in cooperation with the United Nations, to sort this out, not the European Union with European taxpayers’ money. It’s a total waste.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Mr Coburn, you are close enough to catch my eye and to indicate that you are way over time. Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: — Consider what Mr. colleague Zdekhovsky said. We in this category in principle short debates over the current situation of human rights abuses in the world should not address all the problems Nigeria has. Colleagues here in the debate mentioned the problems of this vast rich country, the poverty of people, the problems between north and south, Boko Haram, which killed 20,000 people, disputes between herders and farmers, but we here today are supposed to debate the topic of the suppression of rights and even the murder of Christians in this country. I would love to see this subject really clearly resounded here. We are thus responding to an incident that took place in December, a few weeks ago, in which several dozen Christians were murdered after returning from a service. This is a topic that should be emphasized here. In particular, today we should call on the Government of Nigeria to do everything possible for the possibilities of its citizens, so that they can freely profess their religions, whether Christian or Muslim, and protect that right freedom of faith.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, we all know that Nigeria is a huge country, the most populated country in Africa, and we all know that it is devastated by injustice and violence, not only on religious grounds but also on social, economic and political grounds. That is why it happens that Nigeria is one of the five priority countries of the Migration Partnership and in that context I myself have been a member of a delegation to Nigeria on a number of occasions with some other colleagues here. Migration – illicit migration routes – is at the origin of massive and gross human rights violations aimed mostly at women and defenceless children.  This resolution tackles the call on the fight against Boko Haram and its terrorism, but also addresses the Nigerian authorities, calling for reform of the security forces, to make sure that they prevent extrajudicial executions, arbitrary detentions and torture, and reform of the criminal judicial system to make sure that the law is enforced to fight violence, terrorism and corruption, which is massive in Nigeria.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, Nigeria is a very large country with tremendous population growth. From 33 million inhabitants in 1950 it has now reached 190 million. It is a strong economic country, which has rich productive sectors. It's got oil, it's got gas. And yet, we have now come to the point of oil imports into Nigeria. Moreover, at the moment there is a conflict between farmers and nomads, because, in essence, an attempt is being made to grab the land. Therefore, these conflicts are combined simultaneously with religious conflicts. There is a persecution of 30 million Christians in northern Nigeria. There is the terrorist activity of Boko Haram, but it has the potential to act on terrorism today because the very corruption of the regime is a “fertiliser” for its development. There must therefore be significant interventions because, on top of that, from Nigeria, we have a huge number of immigrants to the European Union.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: - Madam President! For more than eight years, Nigeria has to confront serious threats to the safety of its people. The bombings carried out by Boko Haram, violence between ethnic groups or kidnappings have become the country's sad everyday. I sadly accepted the information that recent weeks have brought another escalation in the conflict between Christians and Muslims and shepherds and ranchers. President Buhari reported that additional security forces had been sent to the riot site to find the guilty and hold them accountable and prevent further attacks.
