We will therefore be looking closely at whether President Buhari will live up to his commitment, as the actions so far have not, unfortunately, produced the expected results. In addition, we should call on President Buhari to reform the Nigerian security forces who cannot stop the tide of violence so far.

name: Carlos ITURGAIZ
text: Madam President, we are aware of the very serious problems that are happening in Nigeria in recent times. Jihadist terrorism had been anchored in that African country, and along with the savage attacks of Boko Haram, coupled with his shameful kidnappings, inter-ethnic, religious conflicts, lack of freedoms and violations of human rights in Nigeria unite. Through this resolution, the European institutions must note that thousands and thousands of Nigerians leave that country in search of a place where they can live in peace and freedom. And a part, a large part of them, too, is the Christian minority, which, as in other African countries, are being persecuted, harassed and killed. That is why our European institutions must support this group of Nigerian Christians and give them resources so that they can express their faith in complete freedom.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Madam President! Nigeria because of its size, location, population occupies a completely key position in Africa and is a place that echoes all the geopolitical, political and social problems of this continent. We must do everything to give full support to the Nigerian authorities in the fight against Boko Haram. It takes absolute precedence. Of course you have to judge how this fight is conducted, but the foreground is to protect people from terrorism. Of course the world needs, Africa needs Nigeria consolidated, but strictly political tensions should be resolved through dialogue. That is why it is so important that the problems associated with the activities of the IPOB movement in the south are also addressed by political dialogue. Violence must be countered by force, differences must be resolved through dialogue.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: — I would like to first appreciate the positive shift that has occurred in Nigeria actually since the 1990s. The last presidential election, held in 2015 and when President Buhari was elected, is rated as the most transparent in the entire period of this democratization process. However, this enumeration of the positives de facto ends, because if we really look at how rich in mineral wealth Nigeria is, and how little that wealth goes into society, you I think that is the underlying problem that is seen in Nigeria. I would also like to comment on the attack on Christians. The basic duty of any government is to ensure the protection of life and safety for its citizens. If there is an attack on Christians because of their religion, of course it is unacceptable, and we must condemn it with full responsibility, and I join my colleagues, who have already done so. As far as Boko Haram is concerned, we must of course help the government to resolve this situation. It remains to be seen that that basic military effort again rests with the government of Nigeria.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — EP must respond where such lawlessness happens. Last week another 73 Christians were murdered in Benue. They are victims of the armed herders of the Fulb tribe. These herders, in accordance and essentially with the support of government policy, obtain grazing for their herds precisely at the expense of Christian farmers. So the problem of drought is becoming a problem for religious conflict and we believe the government should address this situation and should not just take into account it. That is why we ask the government of President Muhammad Buhri to respond. It is essentially similar to a statement issued by bishops in Nigeria asking the Nigerian government to protect its citizens and punish the raiders. Government must be a guarantee of safety and a mediator of dialogue.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, yesterday, suicide bombers killed at least 12 people in the northeast of Nigeria. On the same day, a Canadian and an American citizen were kidnapped in Nigeria, and two policemen were killed in the exchange of gunfire with the kidnappers. It is a sad reminder of how volatile the security situation in the country still is and how crucial it is to address the situation in order to unleash Nigeria’s immense potential.  Nigeria is Africa’s most populous country and its largest economy. It is a country of great natural resources, but even more so, it is a country of entrepreneurs, artists, scientists and a country of innovation. We, as the European Union, are investing strongly to help the people of Nigeria bring their country forward. We invest in innovation, for instance, with the Digital4Development initiative, in energy efficiency, in local entrepreneurship, in the Green Economy and in the fight against climate change.  The European Investment Bank is about to increase its portfolio in the country. The visit of Vice-President Ansip to Abuja last year is a good illustration, among others, of this broad partnership. Yet, an unstable security situation is holding back Nigeria’s potential. Boko Haram continues to carry out frequent attacks in the northeast of the country. The attacks have mostly affected the majority Muslim communities in the region, with little regard to the religious or ethnic origin of its victims.  Nigeria is now engaged in a major counter-offensive, alongside Niger, Chad and Cameroon. We have supported their multinational Joint Task Force since the very outset, both politically and financially. There is, however, a long way to go to secure peace, security and long-term stability in the country.  We are also firmly committed to the protection of human rights in Nigeria, including in conflict situations, and we have mobilised all our tools to achieve this goal: diplomacy, development cooperation and humanitarian aid. Let us not forget that Nigeria is now home to 1.7 million internally displaced persons. The EU has already mobilised over EUR 155 million to address the humanitarian crisis, and an additional EUR 250 million for development in the northeast.  There are other violent conflicts in Nigeria, including in the southeast, the Biafra area, and the oil-rich Niger Delta. Clashes between farmers and herdsmen in the so-called middle belt have caused hundreds of deaths. While the herders are mainly Muslim and the farmers mainly Christian, the conflict reflects the limited access to land fuelled by climate change and demographic growth. We, however, share the concern that conflicts can turn more religious with time, with dire potential consequences.  The situation of minorities and vulnerable groups is also a concern to us, and a key subject for discussion. The European Union has made its views very clear that discrimination against certain religious, ethnic or gender groupings should not be tolerated and that it is the responsibility of any state to protect its citizens.  The upcoming elections in February 2019 will likely add to the complexity. I wish to thank the European Parliament for the pivotal role it has played in our election observation missions, cementing the role of the EU as a key political player. High Representative/Vice-President Mogherini hopes to visit Nigeria again in the near future for the next ministerial dialogue, in order to raise our shared concerns and to push our cooperation forward.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: — The debate has ended. The vote will take place on Thursday 18 January 2018. Written statements (Rule 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: in writing. — I would like to express my concern about the situation in central Nigeria, where clashes between ethnic groups engaged in cattle farming and settled farmers have intensified. This conflict has escalated in recent decades as a consequence of population growth, climate change and associated waves of drought and the progressive desertification of northern Nigeria, and more recently also as a result of activity by the terrorist group Boko Haram. These factors force predominantly Muslim herding peoples to move towards the south, thus coming into conflict with predominantly Christian settled ethnic groups engaged in agriculture. Christians, who have lived in these areas for centuries, have to contend with the aggression of influx groups seeking areas to graze cattle. As a result of the accompanying clashes last year alone, more than 1.5 thousand people were killed and 100,000 were displaced. I appeal to Nigeria's president, Mr Muhammadu Buhari, to fulfil his declarations and take firm steps for stabilisation in central Nigeria, as well as intensifying action against Boko Haram in the north. It is crucial to create economic opportunities for herding groups deprived of access to pastures, as well as to speed up work on a regional Great Green Wall project to curb the progressive desertification of the northern part of the country. These actions will address the causes of conflict in both the short and long term.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: — The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on the cases of human rights activists Wu Gan, Xie Yang, Lee Ming-che, Tashi Wangchuk and Tibetan monk Choekyi (2018/2514 (RSP)).

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: author. – Madam President, economic interests have become increasingly important in EU-China relations, sadly overshadowing the EU’s commitment to promoting human rights across the globe. In this context, the urgency resolution we are debating today comes as a timely reminder that we can, and must, reverse this trend. This resolution underlines the need to shift our focus and finally engage in a meaningful discussion on the importance of fundamental freedoms in our bilateral relations. This is necessary if we wish to establish a sustainable partnership with China, our second biggest trading partner. Two Tibetans are named in the resolution: Tashi Wangchuk, a language rights activist, and the Buddhist monk Choekyi have been imprisoned and subjected to inhumane treatment merely for defending Tibetan culture. No evidence has been presented against Mr Wangchuk, while monk Choekyi’s health is deteriorating without proper medical care. Such treatment is clearly in violation of the Constitution of the Republic of China, which guarantees freedom of religion and upholds the rights of minority nationalities. The cases presented in this resolution have raised fears that Chinese criminal law might be abused to persecute minorities, and we should not remain silent on such developments. Rather, the EU must urge Beijing to end the repression of Tibetan culture through religious persecution, anti—Buddhist campaigns and the so-called patriotic education approach. In addition, it should call on the Chinese Government to resume the dialogue on Tibet’s status with the Tibetan administration and finally reach a solution that grants it genuine autonomy within the framework of the Chinese Constitution.

name: Bas BELDER
text: Submitter. — (NL) First of all, I fully endorse the final paragraphs 16 and 17 of the joint resolution on the need and urgency of a united and strong position of all 28 EU Member States on the serious human rights situation in China. As an illustration, I would like to mention the kidnapping and conviction on Chinese territory of Taiwanese citizen Lee Ming-cheh. The position of his brave wife, Li Ching-yu, I am happy to give this to reflect on. I quote: 'If China believes that my husband's actions — spreading democratic values and helping the families of political prisoners — pose a threat to China's national security, then Taiwan's citizens will not only oppose any affiliation to China, but also hesitate to maintain close relations with China.” Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, to think about, here, inside and outside China.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: author. — (DE) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen. China has made significant progress in its development over the past 30 years on the economic rights and social rights of its citizens. But, unfortunately, we note that the opposite has been the case in political rights and human rights in recent years: there is a backward step, there is much more repression, there is much less freedom of expression. I agree with colleagues who say that this is actually contrary to the Chinese Constitution. China should take seriously its own constitution, which guarantees freedom of expression and the protection of minorities. This is not the case today — neither in dealing with the people of Tibet, nor in dealing with the Uighurs and other minorities, and certainly not in people who have a different view from the prevailing opinion in the country. We have to defend ourselves against this, and that is the expression of this urgency. The EU understands human rights as an integral part of its foreign policy. Here too, I agree with colleagues who call on all Member States to take a uniform approach to this fundamental issue, and that economic pressure from China does not cause soft knees, where individual countries no longer participate in the consensus of values that we have. This is very important. There are not many countries in the world that defend these human rights. The EU must do so, and we call on China to take its own constitution seriously.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Jo Leinen, I gave you a little extra time when I shouldn't have, but at least you are the chairman of the Chinese delegation.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: author. — (FR) Madam President, again this year there will be no confectioners' truce for Chinese courts. On the contrary, I would say. They, as usual, condemned in turn while the world had their head at the party. Xie Yang and Wu Gan have just joined the list of Christmas convicts, which included last year the Nobel Peace Prize Prize Liu Xiaobo, who died in detention, as we know, we talked about it. Exactly what is now feared for the Bonze Choekyi, which has been flazed for two years after celebrating the anniversary of the Dalai Lama, and now seriously ill in prison. Tashi Wangchuk is waiting for his sentence, which should fall from one moment to the next — perhaps up to 15 years in prison, for defending the use of Tibetan in school. I do not forget, of course, Lee Ming—cheh, the Taiwanese who we were talking about last year as well. Television confessions that are scripted, imposed, acts of torture, a conviction rate of Chinese courts that close to 100%: this is what Xi Jinping's China looks like. Four years after adoption — in fanfare! — a reform for a rule of law, the Chinese President is increasingly tightening the vice around those who try criticism, until it relegates China to the global tail platoon in respect of fundamental rights, according to the ranking of the World Justice Project. Beijing must release these prisoners of conscience. European diplomacy must weigh all its weight so that the regime finally guarantees the fundamental rights of its citizens, rights enshrined in the Chinese constitution. In short, it is time to see the Chinese giant move from a state of law to a rule of law.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Author. — Today we will vote on people who fight nonviolently for human rights in China. It is e.g. Wu Gan, who was sentenced to 8 years for publishing articles. He is Xie Yang, a lawyer who specializes in human rights and was tortured for his activities. He is Lee Ming-che, a democracy activist from Taiwan who was sentenced to 5 years despite being effectively a citizen of another country. Tashi Wangchuk is in jail for defending the right of Tibetans to study in their own language. Tibetan monk Zhökji was arrested for celebrating the Dalai Lama's birthday. The situation in China and Tibet has been deteriorating from a human rights perspective, at least since current President Xi Jinping firmly seized power. There are thousands of political prisoners in China, 7,500, and we only mention some. I would like to thank all of my associates for their cooperation on this statement and for their support.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, under the reign of President Xi Jinping, the human rights situation has deteriorated sharply. Members of Tibetan and Uighur minority communities are persecuted, tortured and imprisoned on the basis of separatism. The Chinese opposition, on the other hand, are treated in a similar manner on charges of subverting state power. False accusations disguised as legitimate serve to curb the oppressed Chinese society, including minorities. The Chinese Government applies well-known methods of totalitarian, communist regimes to the detriment of fundamental human rights guaranteed by its own constitution. Moreover, by throwing away its responsible international, democratic commitments, it is now seeking to extend its offensive practices to Taiwan. In view of all this, we demand that the Chinese Government release its prisoners without delay and unconditionally, including Ilham Tohti's prominent Uighur intellectuals, the flagbearer of peaceful interethnic dialogue.

name: Ana GOMES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (PT) Madam President, the repression of Chinese activists and the Tibetan monk we are debating here today demonstrates how the People's Republic of China continues to shoot itself in the foot in trying to silence them. The European Union must, in public and private, persuade Beijing to abandon censorship and repression against minority activists and representatives such as Tibet. The European Union cannot look aside as Beijing prepares to pass a package of laws which, on the pretext of combating terrorism, restricts fundamental freedoms and rights or a law on the management of international NGOs aimed at placing human rights associations and defenders at the mercy of the authorities of the state. We must, in a concerted and strategic manner, press to ensure that, during the forthcoming universal periodic review of the People's Republic of China, we must ensure that Chinese civil society is heard and participates in the process. The European Union also has a strategic interest in a loyal relationship with China in terms of global security, in which Beijing must contribute constructively and not hide in its status as the Security Council in order to act in a parallel international framework and to violate its own obligations in in accordance with the UN Charter and all other conventional instruments that China has subscribed to.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — We remember the Tiananmen massacre, we defended Liu Xiaobo, persecuted for the rest of his life. Now another list of Tibetan monks, lawyers like Wu Gan and even Taiwanese human rights defenders. Let us not forget that a state that shows special cruelty to its best citizens, as well as citizens of other states, is our strategic partner. Dialogue on human rights is not a sufficient instrument for the impact of the European Union. These actions of the Republic of China, which we mention today, should be the subject of particular condemnation from all countries in the European Union.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, unfortunately, this case involving human rights activists again shows us that China is systematically violating a wide range of fundamental human rights, including freedom of expression, association and religion and minority rights. Therefore, I call on the Chinese authorities to end all cases of human rights violations and to release immediately and unconditionally all human rights defenders, activists, lawyers, journalists and petitioners who have been detained for their human rights work. The Chinese authorities must immediately stop harassing minorities in the country, which for years have been under pressure. As a matter of fact, very recently, together with other colleagues, we nominated Ilham Tohti for the Nobel Peace Prize because of the continuing crackdown on the Uighur minority and his efforts to protect the rights of his ethnic group. China is an important strategic partner of the EU but the country has to respect and protect the rights and freedoms of its citizens who think differently and have opinions about government policies. Last, but not least, I call on the EU to put the protection of human rights defenders at the top of the agenda of the next EU-China Dialogue on Human Rights.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, fifteen years in prison, with the sole fault of being a Tibetan: this is the penalty that risks being imposed on Tashi Wangchuk, a shopkeeper who has had the brazen to claim in a New York Times video the sacrosanct right of Tibetans to study in their native language. Tashi is thus accused of inciting separatism and jailed for as much as two years. He now risks his sentence being extended to fifteen years and, when the conviction rate is 99%, the risk is practically a certainty. Like Tashi, Wu Gan, Xie Yang, Lee Ming-che, Choekyi and many others, yet another victims of Xi Jinping's repression of patriotic education towards anyone who deviates from his line. Journalists, human rights defenders, Buddhist monks and religious minorities such as those of the Uighurs and Falun Gongs. The fight against terrorism is always an excellent excuse to implement increasingly rigid surveillance and censorship. Perhaps China will indeed become, by the middle of the 21st century, the world's first power, as Xi Jinping envisions, but it must be so too and above all of the rule of law, not just trade.

name: Thomas MANN
text: Madam President! Two years ago, the monk Choekyi was arrested from Phurbu Monastery and sentenced to four years' imprisonment. His so-called crime: he celebrated the eightieth birthday of the Dalai Lama. During detention, his already attacked health deteriorated significantly. Family members are not even allowed to bring medication on already limited visits. We demand the release of this monk! A second serious case concerns human rights activist Tashi Wangchuk. He has been fighting for years to preserve the Tibetan language and oppose the suppression of Tibetan culture. In March 2016, he was charged with allegations of separatism. He's facing 15 years in prison. It is time for China to distance itself from intimidation, arrests, suppression of freedom of expression and freedom of religion, not only in the framework of the dialogue with the EU. China may be a power economically, but it is not humanitarian.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, a shopkeeper who advocated for the teaching of the Tibetan language so that future generations of Tibetans would not grow up unable to speak their mother tongue is charged with ‘inciting separatism’ and risks one-and-a-half decades of his freedom. A monk is jailed for celebrating the birthday of his spiritual leader, and is forced by prison authorities to perform hard labour despite failing health, while his family is restricted from meeting him or bringing him medicine. Peaceful human rights activists are imprisoned and reportedly subjected to torture. Events like these are the norm in China. What is the EU’s response? Just recently it agreed on an EU-China Tourism Year. In the face of such grave human rights abuses, it is vital for us to keep a firm, principled and united response, especially in the light of China’s assertive foreign policy that aims to silence criticism through informal investment agreements on the one hand and bullying and intimidation on the other.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this is not the first time that we have debated cases reflecting the deteriorating human rights situation in China, which have intensified since Mr Xi Jinping took power in 2012. In 2017, after appealing to the Chinese authorities to release the Nobel Peace Prize winner Liu Xiaobo for medical treatment, we received the sad news of the death of this dissident who cried louder and clearer than anyone else for democracy. Today, once again, we are talking about the case of five activists who have in common fighting for human rights in China and are themselves victims of repression, who denounce all accused of subversion and incitement to separatism by the Chinese regime. Ladies and gentlemen, next year we are celebrating the thirtieth anniversary of the Tiananmen massacre, an unfortunate milestone in China's history, which clearly portrays the repression of religious, cultural and political expression of modern China. The European Union can only call on the Chinese authorities to respect human rights and immediately release these political prisoners.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: — Madam President, yes, the Chinese mastodon, with its enormous commercial and industrial power, seduces as much as he frightens. This will for power takes the human rights issue to the background and, if Chinese leaders accept economic globalization, they stubbornly refuse to take into account human rights, democracy and justice, which would naturally undermine their power. The European Union must vigorously denounce what is happening in China, and urge the immediate release of activists and lawyers incarcerated under false pretexts. Human rights are one of the fundamental values of the European Union and every European leader, every leader of the EU Member States, when visiting China, must express that. For my part, I would have liked the President of the French Republic, during his recent visit, to address these issues publicly, the only way to make the Chinese government understand that we will never accept that business takes precedence over human rights.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: — I would also like to support in my performance all political prisoners who are persecuted by the government regime in China. Their account was given by Mrs colleague Šojdrova, and I will only be referred to it. Of course anyone who is wrongly prosecuted should deserve our support and he needs to be expressed solidarity. What I find important is the communication that truly political rights are an absolute illusion in China. What a single EU needs right now is to appeal to member states for uniform action on China. But I think we should also reach into our own conscience and say how many delegations we send to China and how many delegations speak and raise the issue of human rights. It's our duty not to be afraid to talk, we can, so please take advantage of this in our travels and to China.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the five cases we have discussed today raise serious concerns about due process and respect for the rule of law in China, and more generally about the state of human rights and freedom of expression in the country. During the trials of peaceful campaigners Lee Ming-cheh and Tashi Wangchuk, blogger Wu Gan, and lawyer Xie Yang, we observed procedural irregularities that are inconsistent with China’s criminal procedural law and constitution. We have followed all these cases very closely and we have voiced our concerns both with public statements and in our direct contacts with the Chinese authorities. When accounts came to light that Xie Yang and Wu Gan had been tortured, we immediately called upon the Chinese authorities to investigate promptly and to punish those responsible. Lee Ming-cheh has recently been sentenced to five years in prison for exercising his freedom of expression. This right should be guaranteed under China’s constitution, and not punished. We call for the release of all the individuals mentioned, not least of Tashi Wangchuk, who is still on trial and is facing up to 15 years in prison for allegedly inciting separatism. The main prosecution evidence against him appears to be a video published by the New York Times where he did no more than advocate the rights of Tibetans to study in their mother tongue.  The Tibetan monk Choekyi was reportedly arrested for celebrating the Dalai Lama’s birthday in 2015. The news of his deteriorating health situation is troubling. We urge the Chinese authorities immediately to grant him parole on humanitarian grounds and to allow him to receive the necessary medical assistance. Already last summer at our human rights dialogue with China, we emphasised the deteriorating situation in relation to civil and political rights in China. Such deterioration contrasts very starkly with the significant improvements in the Chinese people’s standard of living. We have witnessed improvements in the sphere of some civil rights and we have welcomed the commitment by the Chinese authorities to ensure legal representation for greater numbers of criminal defendants. The Chinese authorities have committed to promoting law-based governance and to the creation of a modern and prosperous society, but these goals are impossible to achieve when the full range of human rights is not guaranteed. There can be no sustainable development without a fair justice system and without freedom of expression for all. This continues to be our message to the Chinese authorities and we will keep raising all these individual cases until justice is finally done.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: — The debate has ended. The vote will take place at the end of discussions today. Written statements (Rule 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: in writing. — (NL) The N-VA is concerned about the human rights situation in China. Under the leadership of President Xi Jinping, China is addressing the world, but is moving further and further into a dictatorship. The harsh action against peaceful protest and the persecution of hundreds of courageous demonstrators are proof of this. The N-VA delegation deplores this and therefore supports the resolution before us which strongly condemns the penalties imposed on activists Wu Gan and Lee Ming-che, human rights lawyer Xie Jang and defenders of the Tibetan identity Tashi Wangchuk and monk Choekyi. Economic prosperity must go hand in hand with democratic reforms. We therefore urge Xi Jinping and his government to release all innocent political prisoners, respect international human rights treaties and respect the cultural identity of all peoples. Finally, we call on the European institutions and the Member States to continue their relations with China to promote human rights and to put pressure on the regime to implement the necessary reforms.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: — The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on the Democratic Republic of the Congo (2018/2515 (RSP)).

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: Author. — Madam President, it is necessary and we ask that President Joseph Kabila commit to hold parliamentary elections before 23 December 2018. And presidential election. Only so the conflict in the Congo can weaken in intensity. The region has been and is strongly destabilised. Government forces want to silence civic protests. In 2016, only in three days, 62 protesters were killed by law enforcement. In November 2017, 59 activists, journalists and other political opponents were still illegally detained. Naturally, we ask to be released. Children are recruited into the army, torture of the population continues. All this must stop and the guilty to pay. Sanctions and investigations must be extended to the highest dignitaries and any responsible person who must be responsible for war crimes and crimes against humanity.

name: Soraya POST
text: author. – Madam President, the recent arrests and killings of peaceful demonstrators and human rights defenders in the Democratic Republic of Congo are of great concern. In a country where human rights, democracy and the rule of law are extremely under threat, our support for strengthening civil society is crucial. In the Democratic Republic of Congo, tens of thousands of children are working in mines for multinationals, and militias are using them as soldiers. The high incidence of rape and other forms of sexual violence against women is shocking. We ask the authorities of the Democratic Republic of Congo to release immediately and unconditionally all detained human rights defenders and to hold free and fair elections in the coming year. Human rights activists must be able to carry out their work for democracy, equality, social justice and the rule of law without fear. We stand with the Congolese people in their fight for democracy and peace.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: author. — (FR) Madam President, 'The DRC, or disorder as the art of government', was a major evening newspaper from my country. This country is sick of its wealth. Its president, who has been in office for 17 years almost the day, wants to remain in power at all costs. In Kasai alone, where the worst massacres of recent months have occurred, there are nearly 5,000 deaths, 89 mass graves and 1,000,000 displaced persons. The government is amending the mining code to ensure that Congolese people benefit from mining — sic. We could laugh at it, if it wasn't so dramatic. Mining regions are devastated by conflicts; the responsibility of multinationals is constantly being pointed out in international relations. The former colonies seem to lose their hands, which probably explains why Belgium will fundamentally review its cooperation there. So how can we help the Congolese people? Probably by supporting an international investigation into the massacres, but above all by forcing European companies to respect human rights, starting with legislation on blood ores.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: author. – Madam President, the situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo continues to deteriorate. The elections keep being postponed and, worse, there is violent repression, and there are killings and widespread human rights violations, such as rape and torture. Protests held in December against the President were met with live ammunition, tear gas and rubber bullets fired by security forces. Meanwhile, the UN is denied access to hospitals, morgues and detention facilities and has not been allowed to observe the demonstrations, and human rights defenders are being arrested without warrants. So we call on the Congolese authorities to immediately and unconditionally release all prisoners of conscience, and to carry out independent investigations into the violent repression of protests. We urge the UN, too, to play a role here, as well as the International Criminal Court (ICC), looking into the claims that criminal activities and crimes against humanity have been perpetrated by the security forces in Kasai Province. It is good to see that the EU has now adopted targeted sanctions. Individuals who perpetrate human rights violations must be held to account.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: Submitter. — On 29 and 30 December 2017, seven human rights activists were arrested. They're still stuck. I would like to mention them all here: Carbone Beni, Mino Bompomi, Roger Katanga Mwenyemali, Bony Dickson Mputu, Grâce Tshiunza, Cedrick Kalonji and Arciel Beni. They are all active for the Filimbi movement. I'm also worried about the fate of Palmer Kabeya. Nobody seems to know where this human rights activist went. Elections in Congo are being postponed over and over again, and President Kabila is increasingly hitting on activists and the opposition. People with guts who, after decades of violence, have still not given up their courage. People who have the best interests of their country. Meanwhile, a humanitarian disaster is taking place in the country: about 4 million children are in danger of being seriously malnourished. Millions of people are on the run internally in the country, and especially in the provinces of Kasai and Tanganyka the situation is very serious. Meanwhile, there is a huge shortage of money in the aid agencies. Who else pulls the wallet for this country? Who sees a future in that? Last Christmas I finally read that book by Naipaul, “A bend in the river”, a bend in the river. Naipaul sketches a huge image of the country. There is a form of resignation. It's never gonna be a thing again! The Congolese people cannot afford that resignation. And neither can we.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: author. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are here, again, again, for the umpteenth time, talking about the human rights situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. All the past resolutions that we have discussed, voted on and passed in this House have unfortunately not resulted in anything good. It is disheartening that the years pass and the situation should always remain the same: an entire country at the mercy of the constant postponements of a leader attached to the armchair and that now has come so far as to get shot on the crowd protesting, demanding compliance with the agreement according to which a vote should be taken by 2017. New elections are set for December 2018: we are ahead of another year in which we hope that the situation will not deteriorate further, a year in which it will be vital that the international community intervene by all diplomatic means to avert a worsening situation which could lead to even more serious unrest. A year to finally guarantee elections to which this people are entitled under international norms and its own Constitution.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: author. — Madam President! I think today we are all united. The topic of the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo has kept coming back since our term. He also appeared on the occasion of discussing the conflict of minerals, so-called bloody minerals. We are talking about a very rich country, with great opportunities where, however, the current political and humanitarian situation and the security and living conditions of citizens are at their lowest level, for one reason alone, namely because President Kabila is trying to extend his term by breaking the constitution and without fulfilling the conditions proposed in joint declarations by congress of bishops, social organizations or human rights defenders. That is why I think it is very important at this point to guarantee the security of citizens in the face of numerous murders and the attack of demonstrators by security forces. All this leaves more than 6 million people at risk of starvation and there have already been the first cases of cholera epidemics. This rich country is in danger, therefore meeting the conditions that determine free elections can be the only solution and the way to restore stability in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, and at the same time allow the European Union and the Commission to strengthen the humanitarian aid that so very much is needed in this country right now.

name: Seán KELLY
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa PPE. – A Uachtaráin, ní hé seo an chéad uair atáimid ag caint faoi Phoblacht Dhaonlathach an Chongó agus is dócha nach é an uair dheireanach é, agus ní dea-scéal é. Personally, I am deeply concerned at the worsening security situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) and I condemn all acts of violence. The evidence from human rights organisations of violence perpetrated on women and children by the Congolese security forces and government-backed militias is overwhelming. When you do not have elections, as happened last year – the elections in 2017 were postponed – it is hard to get progress, so I strongly urge the Congolese Government to hold presidential elections on 23 December 2018, and I also urge it to align any bills with the consolidation of international human rights standards, and to establish an electoral timetable in order to ensure progress and the support of the European Union. I welcome investigations into the attacks on UNESCO troops which left 15 peacekeepers dead, and I urge the EU and its Member States to make human rights values a priority in finding a solution to the conflict in the DRC, and also, from a humanitarian point of view, to deal with the outbreak of the cholera epidemic there.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Madam President, in some world scenarios the European Union is brutally showing its incapacity, its impotence. The Democratic Republic of the Congo is one such country. How many times have we addressed in this House how important it is that the Democratic Republic of the Congo not fall into a definitively hostile hole, how fundamental that country is for the region and for the whole continent, that injustices occur one after another and that we are absolutely unable to stop them. Just two messages in a minute I have. First, the date of the elections must be maintained at all costs in December 2018; the time for the Congolese is over. Secondly, to the Congolese Government: they cease to massacre their youth, stop arresting, torturing and murdering their youth, protecting their youth and protecting their country.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — (NL) On 19 January 2015, exactly three years ago tomorrow, thousands of Congolese students started their courageous protest against postponing the presidential elections. By means of all kinds of delay manoeuvres, President Kabila is still sitting on his throne, and unfortunately blood continues to flow through the streets of so many Congolese cities. At the end of 2017, this bloodshed reached absolute low, when a demonstration led by the Congolese church was crackled down. Particularly tragic, especially because the church has always played a conciliatory and constructive role. The European condemnation of violence was appropriate, but it was simply too short. After three tumultuous years in which numerous opponents lost their lives, we as the European Union cannot look away any longer. The fact that European companies and European Member States continue to sign contracts with Kabila for energy supplies, infrastructure and military cooperation is cynical and further exacerbates the political crisis in Congo. I call on the EU to further extend targeted sanctions against corrupt members of the Congolese regime and urge Member States to review their links with Kabila.

name: Javier NART
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — Madam President, the European Union is hypocritical condemning its voluntary helplessness. I'm sick of complaints and sick of convictions that are irrelevant to President Kabila and his kleptocracy. Besides condemning, we have to do. And we can do! And we must do! There is a holocaust in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. And that holocaust has an answer. First, Article 96 of the Cotonou Agreement, which requires democratic behaviour in order to continue to have the benefits of the European Union. We don't do it. I'm sick of convictions. Second, in the Member States of the European Union, where the assets of the Congo kleptocracy reside, simply go to court, seizure them and take away wealth from the murderous kleptocrats who are the Government of Congo. If we do not take concrete attitudes, honestly, another role at all gives me an infinite — I would say — rejection. I am sick of hypocrisy in the European Union. I don't want one more conviction. I want shares.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Madam President, the Democratic Republic of the Congo is facing serious simultaneous crises. In addition to the very serious social and humanitarian political situation are heinous floods that have destroyed the homes of thousands of people or an outbreak of cholera lurking the country, in addition to the constant savage plundering of its natural resources and the accompanying human rights violations, many of them committed by companies, by entrepreneurs Europeans. In addition, the acts of violence during the anniversary of the New Year agreements claimed the lives of many demonstrators. The European Union must demand that the Government abandon the use of violence against peaceful demonstrators, respect for freedom of expression, as stated in its Constitution — including free access to social networks — and that religious freedom be guaranteed. Although modest, the commitments reached by the European Union through the European Development Fund and aimed at such priority areas as the health system, environment and agriculture or strengthening democratic governance and the rule of law are essential. This is the least that the Congolese people deserve after decades, first, of colonial plunder and, now, neoliberal plunder.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Madam President, those who put Joseph Kabila in power no longer know how to get rid of it. The President takes advantage of the division of his opposition and insecurity to remain in power. The forces that participated in the peace and transition agreements, including the Church, are overtaken by the behavior of the existing power. A European sanctions regime, unfortunately, is likely to be ineffective: it is against the law, it will support some of the Congolese opinion behind its president and will be an example of the principle of “double standards” because, when the criminal Paul Kagame, or Mr Sassou-Nguesso — and there are others — change the constitution to keep in power, we don't say anything! The only solution is a Security Council action that takes into account the whole situation of the Great Lakes in order to obtain, through diplomacy and force, a negotiated process. France, Russia and the United States can take this initiative, start substantive work linking security and development to bring peace back to Africa of the Great Lakes, and if necessary, impose it by force.

name: Maria ARENA
text: — Madam President, the Democratic Republic of the Congo is a country which in Central Africa should play an essential role: a political role, an economic role, a development role. Unfortunately, this clay-footed giant has been a factor of instability in the region for decades. The wars that took place there, which never really ceased, have killed millions, millions of displaced persons, caused rape, and so on. And all this for the benefit, quite simply, of natural resource operators and kleptocrats. Today, the situation is again very worrying, for the Congolese population in the first place. As you know, President Kabila's term expired in 2016 under the Constitution. Since then, the authorities have continued to take steps to postpone the organization of elections, despite the New Year's Eve agreement signed in December 2017. It is true that the decision has been made to hold elections for 23 December 2018, that recruitment is underway and that a number of things, means are now being put in place. Yet doubt remains, and for good reason: the repression of recent peaceful demonstrations is unacceptable; the reports of the United Nations and FIDH on atrocities in Kasai require reaction and investigation. The death threats facing the heads of human rights activists today are condemnable. The detention of political prisoners, by hundreds, is intolerable and I can continue the list of unacceptable in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. The authorities, if they want to be credible, both with the Congolese population but also internationally, must empower an independent CENI, must release political prisoners, must try the perpetrators of violence and must guarantee the organization of such elections, free and inclusive.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: — I join those Members who believe that the debate makes any sense if it leads to some concrete solution, concrete steps that the EU will be able to push through. Here were words about the fact that we should freeze savings to the criminal representatives of the Congolese regime, that we should reconsider our aid to this state, examine how much money that went to Congo we send, it does not end up in the hands of corrupt representatives of the state power there, but if and whether they even help the simple citizens of this country who live in terrible conditions. Of course, we will not resolve the situation, that is clear, but at least to apply concrete pressure and not just adopt a resolution should be a consequence of this action today. Pressure President Kabila to finally make a presidential election and for there to be — if possible — a proper election that year so that there is a change in the leadership of this country because 2017 is seen as the worst year of contemporary Congo with the greatest violence against the civilian population. (The Speaker agreed to answer the question posed by lifting the blue card (Article 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Maria ARENA
text: “blue card” question. — I fully agree with you on the issue of redirecting aid and perhaps moving towards more humanitarian aid, but you know, corruption issues in the Democratic Republic of the Congo are not on the back of development aid. The corruption problems we have in Congo are produced by international companies that exploit human resources and fill the pockets of Congolese kleptocrats. I therefore call on the EPP to allow the adoption and support of measures which force European companies not to be corruptive. So I ask you the question, Mr. What are the actions that the EPP is prepared to support in this area?

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: answer to the question posed by raising a blue card. — I, as a lawyer, do not recognize the principle of collective guilt. I don't agree that we label businesses a priori without having any evidence of specific causations that someone is a corruptive, just because they're a businessman and that they're in business somewhere. Let's address how aid to Congo specifically flows, how it is specifically used. The Commission should have information on how European money is used in Congo. If a particular enterprise causes criminal activity, corruption, let it be affected of course, but please, the principle of collective guilt built on the ideology that capitalists a priori corrupt do not apply.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: — Madam President, tired of the masked ball of the Congolese government, Monsignor Laurent Monsengwo had to formulate a pamphlet: 'Let the mediocre be clear. ' He referred to the current leaders who had become champions of political imbroglio but, at the same time, unable to respect democratic principles. How can we explain the fact that tear gas was thrown into churches, killed peaceful demonstrators who demanded respect for New Year's Eve agreements, promoted and not respected? It must be acknowledged that the electoral calendar published by the CENI looks like a farce, and history will tell us. Today, all Congolese political actors must meet around a table for a non-violence pact so that the country can pull itself together. With Bishop Laurent Monsengwo, it is really necessary to say: “let the mediocre clear”.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the Congo is a rich country with rich resources, mineral wealth. Unfortunately, however, the Congolese people themselves are not benefiting from this rich country. This is because there is overexploitation by various multinationals. The whole problem at political level arises because Kabila has been in power for 17 years, refusing to hold elections — we have repeatedly discussed the Congo issue here. It was supposedly committed to elections at the end of December 2017. Eventually, these will be in 2018, if they ever do. That causes conflicts, we have too many deaths. What is certain is now that the Congolese leadership must be tackled, sanctions must be imposed, Kabila and his company must be frozen, and there must be sanctions against the European multinationals playing the game there and even take advantage of child labour.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I wonder how many other resolutions we have to vote in this plenary, how many more words we have to listen to in the face of a country that collapses more and more, a country in hand to a criminal, its current President, who is based in turn on a circle of kleptocrats raiding the public thing, who are depriving entire generations of a future, a dream and a life normal and dignified. A character that is allowing, right now, to shoot on protesters, even violate places of worship. How many more times do we have to discuss this The reality is that, perhaps, our own Union is very hypocritical about the affair. Perhaps, in a country that is blessed by nature and cursed by man, a Kabila is comfortable. It's comfortable for our businesses, let's tell the truth. It's convenient for those who wouldn't want to sanction them. And I tell you that we will continue to make 500 more resolutions in the coming years until we have the courage to freeze the assets of this shameful ruling class that governs today in the Democratic Republic of Congo and until we punish our businesses, sanctioning them directly. Just make fun of us and just talk about Cotonou, if we have no desire to apply it!

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: — I join my preorators. We talked about the situation in Nigeria a while ago, but the situation in Congo is really completely different and far worse. I join my colleagues who have condemned the violence committed by government forces, including that sexual violence of incredible proportions against women, postponing elections and the constant deterioration of the situation, it is of course a symptom of today's Congo. On the other hand, I think it is possible to agree with the way Mr colleague Castaldo or Mr colleague Nart spoke, we need to be able to take concrete action because that is what they expect from us not only our constituents, but also people just in the Congo. So let's please try not only to write resolutions, and I welcome them, but also to express those specific procedures, including the freezing of accounts, and to the Member States to act uniformly. That is, I think, our role.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, I also join colleagues who say that we cannot be indifferent to what is happening now in the Congo. Besides, we cannot be indifferent to any violations of human rights. After all, we say in the European Union that we have values relating to human rights, peace, the rule of law and, of course, the serious cases that are happening now in the Congo, the release of prisoners, must take place as quickly as possible. We need to find the levers through which we can intervene because I believe that there must be a unified action of international institutions. I also refer here to the UN, which is passive. The EU must not hesitate to give all support to Congolese citizens. We need to see how, because cessation of aid to the Congo would have an effect on citizens, and I do not think that is what we want. We want justice, we want respect for human rights and punish those who violate human rights.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, Parliament is demonstrating, with this urgency resolution, its keen commitment to addressing the situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). We have been regularly discussing the DRC here, every six months since mid-2016, and you have passed resolutions expressing grave concerns, which have unfortunately been growing with time. The international community has been worriedly watching, over the past couple of years, one of the largest countries in Africa edging towards collapse due to a compounded political, security, humanitarian and socioeconomic crisis. The Council has also been paying attention to the DRC. On 11 December 2017, Foreign Ministers adopted EU conclusions that assess, without any indulgence, the situation in the country and clearly set the strategic course for the months to come. In the meantime, the Commission, through its humanitarian aid department ECHO, is responding to the growing needs of the 13 million Congolese affected by the humanitarian crisis, including 4.35 million internally displaced persons and 1.9 million undernourished children.  The EU is very aware of the importance of monitoring and reporting on the human rights situation in a country in crisis. It has repeatedly emphasised that human rights monitoring and reporting is a crucial part of the mandate of United Nations Organisation Stabilisation Mission in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (MONUSCO) and especially the UN’s Joint Human Rights Office in Kinshasa. The EU promotes regular coverage of DRC issues at the UN Human Rights Council. We were at the forefront in pushing, at the 35th session of the Council in June 2017, for a resolution on the investigation into the events in Kasai. The EU has also internalised in EU law the EU—UN sanctions regime, targeting perpetrators of human rights abuses in the Great Lakes Region. Development aid is carried out through projects which are constantly evaluated and in which funds are set aside for specific purposes. They are currently focusing on food security, health and infrastructure development. EU aid is indeed already focused on supporting the population of the DRC. It should be noted that the EU does not provide budget support to the Congolese Government. Having recourse to Article 96 of the Cotonou Agreement would create huge transaction costs for alternative delivery mechanisms. National systems delivering basic social services cannot function on NGO support alone. The impact of EU support to the health system and to rural development benefits the poor, ordinary people of the DRC, who should not be victimised. As you know, there are complex and entrenched causes for the chronic fragility in the Congo, not least linked to the governance of strategic natural resources. There is, however, international consensus around one issue. Elections are needed to end the current political situation, whereby President Kabila has stayed one full year beyond the end of his mandate. In that context, the European Union has chosen to work closely with the United Nations, the African Union and other essential partners so as to speak and act as one in this direction. There is now a calendar, with elections planned for 23 December 2018; there is a budget; voter registration has made progress; and there is a wealth of technical support provided to the Congo. Yet many possible hurdles could still emerge, representing as many occasions to divert the country from this key objective. Security threats have recently resurfaced in Kasai and with the unprecedented massacre of 15 Tanzanian UN peace-makers in the east on 7 December. We have to be careful and ensure that, while MONUSCO is empowered to respond and neutralise negative forces, there is no manipulation and no distraction. For elections to be credible, full observance of human rights and fundamental freedoms is also needed, as well as clear confidence—building measures on the part of the Congolese authorities. The incidents of 31 December 2017, with the disproportionate use of force by security forces, constitute a sombre development that you rightly stigmatised in the resolution tabled, as did the international community, including the African Union. In conclusion, I reiterate the EU’s commitment to contribute to the stabilisation of this crucial country in Africa. In order to do so, we shall be ready to use not only dialogue and constructive support but also the sanctions instrument, if and when that proves to be the only effective way to create incentives for an environment conducive to elections.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The debate has ended. The vote will take place on Thursday 18 January 2018. (The sitting was adjourned at 11:45 a.m.) Written statements (Rule 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Ivo BELET
text: in writing. — (NL) Migratory pressures in Africa will only increase in the coming years and decades. The population in Africa is growing spectacularly, but economic growth is not keeping pace, and the situation in many regions is unstable and conflicting. Many who are affected will also continue to try to come to Europe. The Democratic Republic of Congo has the highest number of newly displaced persons worldwide. Last year alone, more than 1.9 million Congolese had to flee their homes as a result of flaring violence in Kasai and repression by the regime. The additional EUR 28 million in European emergency aid released last year is important for improving living conditions in reception camps and saving lives, but is obviously far from enough. It is clear that, at the same time, the EU must take on a greater role in tackling the roots of all this misery: not only politically but also economically. We need an ambitious aid programme for the most vulnerable areas in Africa. We need a real Marshall Plan for Africa. An economic recovery plan that builds on the Trust Fund for Africa and Opportunities and creates a perspective for the affected population.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: in writing. — Today we addressed the alarming situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo. The overall situation in the country has steadily deteriorated since 2016 especially in connection with the current President's refusal to step down at the end of his term given by the Constitution. Repression, violence are the order of the day. Also alarming is the fact that the UN has called the situation the highest level of a Level 3 humanitarian crisis. In the resolution, we call on all parties to the conflict for dialogue, an end to violence and to find a peaceful solution for the benefit of all the inhabitants.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: in writing. — Ensuring a high level of protection of human rights standards is the responsibility of each Member State, which means that a state must take active action in the event that the health and life of its citizens are at risk. I would like to emphasise that this also means that all possible and necessary conditions must be created for the supply of humanitarian aid: the provision of necessary hygiene products, food and water supplies. I firmly believe that the success of the social, economic and political development in Congo can only be achieved if peaceful, political solutions to the conflict are taken: the prevention of domestic crimes, the prevention of mass killings, the promoters of armed clashes and the relevant responsibilities applied to the performers. Stabilisation of the political situation in Congo would contribute to the creation of a peaceful global political atmosphere, which is vital for the further growth of both Europe and the world in the economic and all social spheres.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the vote.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Mr President, I recently had the pleasure of visiting the fantastic charity ‘Support 4 Sight’, in Saffron Walden, which assists visually impaired people to maintain their independence and quality of life. They showed me Braille, large print and e-books. Sadly, though, the so-called book famine means that only 5% of published books are ever made accessible to the visually impaired in richer countries, and less than 1% in poorer ones. E—books and the digital revolution ought to help end this by allowing more accessible books to be shared easily and cheaply. That is why copyright law keeping pace with technology is so vital. The ratification and implementation of the Marrakesh Treaty will benefit visually impaired British and European citizens and people in developing countries, so today I also call on the UK Government to ensure that Britain will be a signatory to this Treaty post-Brexit as well, and that it does so with no unreasonable commercial availability checks for charities and libraries. Let us get some clarity on this issue and hear what action they intend to take.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: — Mr President, I fully support the Council's decision to conclude the Treaty of Marrakesh. This is an important step towards facilitating access to printed editions for people with visual impairment and other visual impairments. This crucial copyright act will help nearly 285 million people worldwide to obtain a wide range of works more easily. Materials with an affordable format are extremely expensive to produce, and the European Union is the leader in this regard. In this sense, the conclusion of the Marrakesh Treaty by the European Union will have a strong positive social impact globally. Access to education and culture is a basic human right, not a luxury you can hardly afford. Something we take for granted will finally become known to people with visual problems and dyslexia.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: — Mr President, I support the recommendation for the conclusion on behalf of the European Union of the Marrakesh Treaty to facilitate access to published works for blind people, visually impaired or other disabilities who do not allow the reading of printed material. It is imperative to do everything possible to minimise obstacles making life difficult for people with these disabilities. Access to published works, access to education, access to culture continues to be one of the tasks and objectives that we have to defend here in this Chamber. Of course, we must not forget that sometimes in the quest to make progress, it is possible to create a burden on rightholders. I was delighted to see that concerns were met with great respect, a serious approach and we ended up facing a carefully thought out and well-structured recommendation in the end. Therefore, I repeat: I agree and support the conclusion of this Treaty of Marrakech.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, a happy new year to you. It is very nice to see you back in the chair, and thank you for chairing the session so deftly. This debate is a very interesting little example of the way in which international rules and regulations are presented at regional or continental level. I do not think anyone in this House is going to disagree with the substance of the Marrakesh Treaty, with the exemption from certain copyright rules for visually impaired people, and so on. The only difference is that, at the moment, the United Kingdom is represented in all of that process by one 28th of the Commission whereas, from now on, we will have an independent voice. I think it is worth celebrating the fact that there will be a friendly, independent voice alongside that of our neighbours and allies in the EU27, pushing for a stable and orderly world system based on rules.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: — I supported today's accession to the Treaty of Marrakesh. My colleagues have said that before, this treaty is a good international compromise. On the one hand, copyright protection and on the other hand, access by citizens with a visual handicap to individual copyrighted works. It is a good thing that the EU has signed up to this treaty in this way. Our European values include protecting citizens who have a particular health handicap, and within this philosophy of ours it is a good thing that we approach this treaty.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, Dar ndóigh vótáil me i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo agus is dóigh liom gur maith an obair atá déanta, go háirithe ag an bhFeisire Anderson.  Gan dabht ar bith, caithfimid i bhfad níos mó a dhéanamh do dhaoine atá dall nó do lucht lagamhairc, agus tá suas le 50 000 díobh siúd i mo thír féin agus meastar go bhfuil 30 000 000 duine lagamhairc nó dall san Aontas, ach níl teacht acu ar leabhair, ach ag idir 7% agus 20% díobh.  Dá bhrí sin, is dul chun cinn an-tábhachtach é seo; táimid ag tabhairt an seans sin dóibh teacht ar leabhair gan cur isteach ar chearta na n-údar. Agus freisin, ba mhaith liom fáilte a chur roimh an dul chun cinn atá déanta i mo thír féin agus san Aontas, maidir le daoine go bhfuil an mháchail seo orthu.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: — Mr President, in the European Union, about 250 000 children are reported missing each year, one child every two minutes. Second in terms of these disappearances is the theft of a child by one of the parents and the taking of that child to another country - this is how the figures from Missing Children Europe show us. The interests of children must be protected regardless of legal proceedings between parents — they may be in divorce or have other problems — and regardless of parental conflicts. We need urgent measures to improve in the sense of effectively recognising civil court rulings — especially child custody, if any, because then many abductions take place by the other parent — and legal access must be simplified in such cases. Cross-border disputes with kidnapped children simply need to be resolved quickly.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, I welcome the report drafted by my colleague Tadeusz Zwiefka. This subject comes really close to the core social values of European society, namely safeguarding the interests of children.  Although Parliament’s role in this matter is limited to consultation, I am happy that we managed to achieve a more concrete legislative framework for parental responsibility and cross-border child abduction cases. It is crucial that the best interests of the child are guaranteed in matrimonial matters and therefore I particularly welcome the introduction of the child’s right to be heard. Although it remains to be decided how to abolish, in effect, the principle of exequatur in matters of parental responsibility, I am glad to see that the Commission’s initial proposal has been expanded to include more consideration of children’s rights. Therefore I voted in favour.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: — Mr President, on this material discussed: I, of course, supported him, but I have a lot of reservations because he does not address all the problems associated with cross-border divorces, and child abductions. Of course, it is necessary first of all to accelerate the work of judges, also to improve, to make judges who will really deal with and navigate this issue, and not a judge who addresses one day criminal cases and then goes into civil litigation and doesn't know how to interrogate the child and how the child should be heard. I'd like to give one good example here from Germany. This is the so-called Cochem practice of trying to lead parents to make arrangements, not to judge. That's what I think is missing in this legislation, i.e. something like this positive, and it needs to be added even further in the future.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: — As shadow rapporteur, I voted in favour of my colleague Zwiefka's report - competence, recognition and enforcement of decisions on matrimonial matters and matters of parental responsibility and on international child abduction. While I am a firm supporter of eliminating excessive unjustified bureaucracy, especially when it affects the most vulnerable members of our society, I recognise the importance of subsidiarity and other mutually agreed legislation in relation to family law issues. They are sensitive, least because of their nature. And the competences of the Member States must not be ignored. I therefore strongly encourage better, broader and wide-ranging cooperation in order to provide children with the best possible care, possible legal protection and procedural protection.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: — Mr President, in the debate on this regulation yesterday, I expressed concern that some of the proposals contained in this report will limit the competence of Member States in matters of marriage and family law. After the rapporteur, Mr Zwiefka, some of my concerns were dispelled, but one remained. Amendments 19 and 49 aim at the fact that the court will not be able to refuse to recognise the decision of another Member State in a matrimonial matter. Since an authentic instrument is also considered to be a decision, by adopting these amendments, States would also have to recognise marriage certificates issued in another Member State, even if their own legal system contains a different definition of marriage. States must retain the power to determine what union they consider marriage. That is why I did not support the proposal.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: — Mr President, the youth unemployment rate in the European Union has steadily declined. In 2017, the unemployment rate is 17%, compared to 24% in 2013. Of course it is a joyful thing, but we must continue. I believe that the Youth Employment Initiative and the Youth Guarantee are two powerful instruments in the fight against unemployment and for encouraging young people. Young people need to learn from school to do research, innovation, develop their free spirit and entrepreneurship, and then, of course, they have to benefit precisely in order to be able to implement what they have learned, to do research, to innovate, because that's the only way comes the progress of a countries and obviously create jobs for them. The initiative complements national funding, so we must not rely only on European money, but also finance in our home.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: — Mr President, there is a significant decrease in youth unemployment rates. However, the assessment of the implementation of the Youth Employment Initiative must be based not only on quantitative, but also qualitative indicators. The European Court of Auditors' report reveals that it is difficult to assess the results achieved at the moment. This is mainly due to the lack of monitoring systems and tracking mechanisms for participants emerging from the Youth Guarantee scheme. The Youth Employment Initiative should reach and benefit not only the highly skilled people who live in big cities such as Sofia and Plovdiv. They have easier access to information about professional development opportunities. Young people in small settlements and those in disadvantaged backgrounds should have the same opportunities. This is the biggest puncture of the youth initiative. We need to work towards addressing this trend.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, even if the EU is starting to show the first signs of recovery from the economic crisis, in a number of Member States tackling youth unemployment it still remains a great challenge. Integrating young people that are not in employment, in education or training into the labour market would have benefits in terms of both deepening the internal market and maintaining high social standards. The specific budgetary allocation for the Youth Employment Initiative does not require any cofinancing from the Member States. Therefore, this initiative should also be particularly welcomed by the Member States. In my country, Latvia, for example, on 55% of the planned financing for the period 2014-2020 has so far been implemented, while 70% of the EU’s payment has already been delivered. Considering this, I welcome the report and I have voted in favour. However, I believe that the initiative should be completed with closer scrutiny over implementation, and better information coverage should be ensured at the national level.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: — I supported this initiative, but even last night's debate showed that we are re-fluttering into the open door and that a number of states think or a number of colleagues think that if we put somewhere more money, that we're gonna solve the problem, but we're not gonna solve the problem. The problem isn't that there's little money for different programs. The problem is that a number of young people don't educate themselves in fields that have market applications. A number of parents also don't understand that when their child doesn't have a degree, he can just as well apply as that child who has a college education. And I think that this report does not affect, and for the long term the debate on youth employment simply does not focus on the labour market, which is why I have a number of reservations about this report, and therefore I would not wanted to add in this explanation of the vote to the fact that in the next news we take this into account.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: — Mr President, I voted in favour of implementing the Youth Employment Initiative in the Member States. The last decade and the accompanying economic problems have led to a sharp increase in the number of unemployed people. The most vulnerable in this regard are young people. The youth unemployment rate in Europe rose from 15% in 2008 to 24% in 2013. The answer is to create a youth guarantee with a budget for the 2014-2020 programming period of €6.4 billion, committing Member States to ensure that young people receive a good job offer. Continuation of education, apprenticeship or internship after they are out of work and leave the formal education system. I support this initiative, but at the same time I do not agree with the Commission's excessive intervention in the competence of the Member States, which makes them subject to an obligation for decisions that are right to be taken at national level. This is also the reason why I abstained on this report.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: - Mr President! I voted against this report, not only because it is gibberish quite unique even by the standards of this Parliament, but for fundamental reasons. Please note that the Union is fighting unemployment and we have a lot of unemployment. The Union particularly fights youth unemployment and youth unemployment is even higher. The reason for this unemployment is the action of the European Union. For example, on the issue of youth. We send the youth almost forcefully to a variety of studies and then the youth are too old to work. A man of 22 is too old to learn a profession. We specifically cause youth unemployment, and then we wonder at the results. At the youth site, I would say briefly: Lord God protect me from friends, from enemies I will defend myself.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, bhí áthas orm vótáil ar son na tuarascála seo agus tacaíocht a thabhairt dár bhFeisire Romana Tomc, ó mo ghrúpa féin an EPP; rinne sí an-jab. Dar ndóigh, is é an t-aos óg is mó a bhí thíos leis i rith an chúlaithe eacnamaíochta agus i mo thír féin bhí ar a lán den aos óg dul ar imirce.   Chuaigh siad go Ceanada, chuaigh siad go dtí an Astráil, mo mhac féin san áireamh; ach anois tá feabhas mór tagtha ar an scéal de bharr Scéim Fostaíochta na nÓg anseo ón Aontas agus dea-pholasaithe an Rialtais ag baile.   Mar a dúirt ár dTaoiseach Leo Varadkar inné, tá na daoine óga ag teacht ar ais anois go hÉirinn arís agus ag fáil jabanna.  Ní mar sin atá ina lán áiteanna eile san Aontas, tá suas le seacht déag faoin gcéad den aos óg dífhostaithe trasna na hEorpa agus caithimid díriú orthu siúd, agus go háirithe áiteanna tútacha agus daoine ar a bhfuil máchail.   Tá sé de cheart againn ár ndícheall a dhéanamh chun jab a thabhairt do chuile dhuine.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: — Mr President, I voted in favour of the report because the Youth Employment Initiative is also producing positive results and this programme needs to be continued. However, it is important that we control the use of resources for this programme, highlight its shortcomings and propose improvements. That's what this report is trying to do. It highlights a number of shortcomings, ranging from the unpreparedness of Member States to the lack of methodology for identifying the target groups of the programme, to the tendency to replace own funding of measures to support young unemployed with European resources. The Court's report shows that we still have large reserves to implement this initiative, to implement this programme.

name: Monica MACOVEI
